loans.name: Darlene

texts.en:
Darlene M. and her husband, Raymond, are filled with hopes and dreams for their two children, aged three and eleven. Raymond is a tricycle driver (a motorcycle with sidecar, used for transportation) while Darlene manages her fishing and fish-selling business. Sometimes, the tricycle is used to provide a delivery service for the fish because Darlene has acquired customers from different villages in the town of San Jose, in the province of Antique. If she has only a small volume of fish, Darlene just sells them within their village by taking them directly to people's houses.
As well as owning their tricycle, Darlene and Raymond also have a motor fishing boat as an investment. It is managed by Raymond, and sometimes by other people in their village. Both investments were bought using Darlene’s loans through Kiva partner, ASHI, and both are a big help to Darlene in meeting her family's basic needs.
However, when Darlene thinks about her dream of educating her two children until college, she is aware that she cannot afford this on her current income. Therefore, she is looking for a larger amount of financial assistance, via a loan, in order to sustain and grow her business. She wants to purchase another motor fishing boat because she can see that her fishing and fish-selling business has the potential to generate more profit and could also give people easy access to food.

loans.use: To purchase a motor fishing boat

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 27 years old, married to Nicholas Waititu, and has a one-year-old child. She sells containers for storing water to the residents of Naivasha town. The town is known to have water shortages so people store water in such containers. She has been in this business since 2007.
Betty was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to buy more plastic containers to sell as they are in demand in Naivasha. Her hopes are to grow her business and sell wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more water containers to sell

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester G. is 31 years old, divorced, and has two school-aged children. She is currently in the business of selling green vegetables at the market, and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of rice and beans to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Ester hopes to be able to build a house.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Munyao

texts.en:
R. K. Munyao is 23 years old, single, and does not have any children yet. Her business is located in a very busy market in Thika, a region in Kenya known for pineapple production. R. has been selling fruits, such as oranges, pineapples and bananas, for the last two years. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is fluctuating climate conditions leading to low production. However, she works very hard to keep her business successful.
R. is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more fruits to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to supply her fruits to different parts of the country. Her aspiration is to become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy more fruits to expand her business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane N. W. is 33 years old, single, and has two children aged 7 and 14. She is a very hardworking, humble and down-to-earth lady. Jane has a salon from which she provides hair and beauty services to local women. Her business is located at Gatundu, in a very busy market in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for pineapple production. 
Jane says that her business is profitable and the only major challenge is that there are many other salons in the areas so her customers are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to make sure her business remains successful. Jane is using her loan of 45,000 KES to buy more hair weaves and chemicals to expand her business. In the future, Jane hopes to open her own hair and beauty college. She also hopes to achieve a customer base of 1,000 people.

loans.use: To purchase hair weaves and chemicals

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha C., 40, has been married to Mr. Chanthorn since 1991, and they live in the Muk Kampoul District of Koh Dach, a famous island located 30 kilometers along the Mekong River roughly 15 kilometers northeast of Phnom Penh. Koh Dach has been nicknamed Silk Island because of the many villagers who weave silk on traditional looms.

Sokha has been a silk weaver for 26 years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a construction worker for one year, working in his village. Sokha is now requesting a loan of 500USD to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene N. I. is forty two years old, married and has three children aged between twenty years and fifteen years. Her business is located at Mukiriti, a busy market in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples.

Irene has been selling fruits such as oranges, pineapples, mangoes, plums, pawpaws and bananas for the last ten years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is lack of enough funds. She also gets harassment from the local government. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

Irene is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more fruit to expand her business. She hopes to supply her fruit to different parts of the country in future and wants to be a successful wholesaler.

Irene hopes and dreams of buying a plot for her family. She is God-fearing and friendly.

loans.name: Edwige

texts.fr: T. Edwige est née le 24 Janvier 1953 à Abomey, ville historique du Bénin. C'est depuis 34 ans que Edwige s'est installée au quartier Zogbo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à PADONOU Désiré, un agent commercial en retraite, Edwige est mère de huit enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais seulement un enfant reste encore à sa charge. Le couple vit toujours ensemble à Zogbo avec le seul enfant qui leur reste à charge. Edwige a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au cours secondaire. Mais depuis une dizaine d'année, Edwige mène comme activité la vente de divers articles (pâtes alimentaires, savons, huile végétale, papier hygiénique, lait corporel, fournitures scolaires, etc.) et aussi des boissons de la SOBEBRA, à son domicile. Pour diversifier son activité et augmenter son revenu, Edwige vend également des habits tout cousus et des chaussures, de façon secondaire. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Edwige s'approvisionne. Edwige est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits qu'elle avait bien remboursés. Edwige voudrait renforcer son activité et mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. Pour ce faire, Edwige sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Edwige T. was born January 24, 1953 in Abomey, a historical city of Benin. 34 years ago she settled in the Zogbo neighbourhood of Cotonou, Benin’s economic capital. Married to Désiré PADONOU, a retired commercial agent, Edwige is the mother of eight children, all either in school or having attended school. Only one child is still under her care. The couple lives together in Zogbo with their one remaining child. Edwige herself has attended school up to secondary level, but for the past ten years has set up shop in her home, selling various items such as: pasta, soap, vegetable oil, toilet paper, body milk, school items, etc.), and also SOBEBRA brand beer and soft drinks. To diversify her activity and increase her income, she also sells ready-to-wear clothes and shoes, as a side business. Edwige gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. She is a long-standing client of ALIDé, having already been granted three previous loans, all fully reimbursed. She would like to strengthen her business and be more responsive to customers’ expectations. Therefore, she is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pasta, vegetable oil, soap, soft drinks and beer, etc.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia R. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions and bread in the market and is requesting a loan to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell.

Lucia is 32 years old and is married to a businessman. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.


BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda V., 46, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Ralph V., an aircraft maintenance man, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store and computer shop for quite some time now.

Rosalinda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store and computer shop.

Now, with your help, Rosalinda would like to obtain a PHP 46,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her variety store and for buying equipment and accessories for her computer shop.

Rosalinda dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can have a good and comfortable life with her family.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her store and accessories for her computer shop

loans.name: Rai

texts.en:
Mrs. Rai E. (shown in the photo), age 50, and her husband, Mr. Phat Sam, age 50, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1985 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. One of their sons assists his parents in farming and the other three are in school. 

Rai and her husband have been farming for 20 years. The couple hopes to increase their volume and productivity because their family depends on farming for their income and financial support. Rai is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to purchase fertilizer, seeds, and pesticides to maintain her farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds, and pesticides

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice W. M. is forty years old and married. She has two children, ages seventeen years and three years old. Her business is located at Juja, a busy market in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. 

She has been selling cereals and beans, such as maize, beans, and green grams (mung beans), to the local people for seven years. She says that this business is profitable, but her major challenge is the fluctuating market prices that require her to sell her products at low prices. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more cereals to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to have many business outlets and supply her cereals to different parts of the country. She wants to be a market leader in this business. She is very innovative.

loans.use: Cereals, maize and beans

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
J. Simon sells bread and tea in a restaurant. She is requesting a loan to purchase crates of beer and soda to sell. Simon is 40 years old and is divorced. She has 3 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to live.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy crates of beer and soda to sell

loans.name: Urumuri Group

texts.en:
P. is 32 years old and married. She has four children between the ages of 6 and 15 years old. P. and her family live in Gakenke, a region of Ruhengeri in the Northern Province of Rwanda. P. is the president of a group called Urumuri. This group sells a variety of food for the benefit of each member's family. This is their third successful year in this business. The hours of the business are from 7 AM until late in the evening hours.

This group, of which P. is the president, is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase some new products, including beans and sorghum. With these additional goods, which are highly demanded in this area, this group hopes to increase their sales and their profits. With this loan, this group hopes to earn more profits, and these profits will allow each member to have at least one domestic animal to raise at home.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Rounh

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is 31 years old. She is a married mother blessed with three children, all of whom are students in the local public school. Her husband, Sean, age 33, farms rice to earn a living. 

S. has built a pigpen behind her house where she raises many pigs. Because the pig-raising business is a very profitable one for S. and her family, S. has requested a loan of US $300 to buy additional feed and piglets to raise and then sell during the period when pork commands the highest price.

loans.use: To buy additional feed and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen J. is currently in the business of selling fresh fish in the market and is requesting a loan to stock more fresh and dried fish to sell.  Hellen is 40 years old and married; her husband is a laborer. She has 8 children, who all attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more fresh and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Somaly

texts.en:
Mrs. Somaly S., 52, and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Oem, have been married since 1983 and have six children: three sons and three daughters.  One son is married and lives independently; two sons have full-time employment; two daughters are in school and the other is still young. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Somaly has been a tailor for 10 years, while her husband has been an auto repairer for many years. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $300 to purchase fabric for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase fabric for her tailoring business

loans.name: Anastase

texts.en:
Anastase is 29 years old and is married with two children, 3 and 5 years old. He also takes care of one dependent. He lives in Rulindo, a region situated in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

Anastase has been a driver of a motorbike for a long time and he starts driving from early in the morning until late in the evening hours.

Anastase needs to purchase one more motorbike in order to increase his daily revenue. To this end, he is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, after purchasing his second motorbike, which he has dreamed of, he will hopefully earn more profits.

These profits will be used for an investment in a bakery business as another source of income. With this new business, Anastase will create more jobs for the people of his community.

loans.use: The purchase one more motorbike

loans.name: Katlyn

texts.en:
Katlyn R., 26, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs.  She is a single mother with one child in elementary school. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time.

Katlyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries to replenish her product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she will be able send her child to school and finish a degree while enjoying good health and financial success.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buying groceries to replenish her product inventory

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 30 years old and is still single. She lives in Nyarugenge, a region of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Francoise has been in the business of selling a variety of goods, mostly used at home, for about two years and the hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Francoise is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing a variety of items used at home as the photo indicates. With this loan, she will purchase more items, especially those used for cleaning the house and washing clothes, as those goods seem to be highly in demand. Francoise hopes that it will increase her sales as well as her profits.

With these profits, Francoise will reinvest them in the business for the purpose of building her secure future.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for her store

loans.name: Angèle

texts.fr: A. Angèle est née en 1981 à Abomey-Calavi au Bénin. Mariée à KAKPO Appolinaire, un agent de sécurité, Angèle est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Angèle vit depuis 7 ans environs, avec sa famille au quartier Zogbo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Angèle n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Angèle mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits (riz, huile végétale, pâtes alimentaires, etc.) à son domicile et aussi de façon ambulante. Angèle s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Angèle a déjà 8 ans d'expérience dans l'exercice de cette activité et a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Elle a envie de diversifier ses activités.  C'est pour ca, qu'elle demande un autre crédit d'Alidé.
texts.en:
Angèle A. was born in 1981 in Abomey-Calavi, in Bénin. Married to Appolinaire Kakpo, a safety officer, Angèle is the mother of two children who attend school. Angèle has lived for about 7 years with her family in the district of Zogbo in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Together, the couple takes care of the family. Angèle did not attend school. To fulfill her different responsibilities, Angèle sells various products (rice, vegetable oil, pasta, etc.) from her home and door to door. Angèle gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Angèle already has 8 years of experience with this type of work and has already benefited from two loans through ALIDé. She would like to diversify her work. This is why she is requesting another loan through ALIDé.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase vegetable oil, rice, pasta

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose K. N. is 34 years old and married with two children, 4 and 7 years old. Her husband is a driver. Her business is located at Makonngeni, a busy open air market in Thika, the region in Kenya known for pineapple production. She has been selling cereals such as maize, beans and green grams (mung beans) for the last five years to the local people. She has one employee. She says that her business is profitable and her major challenge is the lack of variety of cereals. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of KES 50,000 to buy more cereals to expand her business and become a distributor. She hopes to become a wholesaler, have many business outlets and supply her cereals to different parts of the country in the future. She is very hardworking and honest.

loans.use: to buy maize, beans and green grams

loans.name: Witinyagukora Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is 41 years old and is married with two children who are 8 and 14 years old.  Beatrice lives in Gakenke, a region of Ruhengeli situated in the Northern Province of Rwanda. There, Beatrice is the president of a group called Witinyagukora.  This group has been in this business of selling tomatoes and vegetables for a long time and the hours of their business are from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m every day.

Beatrice as the president of this group, is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through purchasing some additional goods for sale. Those goods include a large quantity of tomatoes and vegetables. The purpose of adding these goods to their business is that they seem to be highly demanded by a number of customers.  So, with their business of selling tomatoes and vegetables plus the new business of selling fruits, this group hopes to earn more profits. These profits will at least allow their business to expand meaningfully through the reinvestment in the same business.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of fruits, tomatoes and vegetables

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en: Mostafa is a 47-year-old married man with 8 children, 5 of whom are still unemployed. He has been working as a painter since 1999. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his children's needs. He works on a freelance basis upon client request due to his good business reputation. Today, Mostafa is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy new painting tools and supplies to satisfy his customers' needs.

loans.use: new painting tools and supplies

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeun Y. is a local cultivator who has been farming since 2000. She, age 41, is married with two kids, both of them attending school. Her husband helps feed the family by investing in the ox-sale trade.

Soeun Y. needs some supplies to serve her in her farming business this year. Therefore, she requests a loan of 500 USD to to buy fertilizer, seeds, and a water pump, which will allow her to grow crops on her farmland.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds, and a water pump

loans.name: Najah

texts.en:
Najah M. is a housewife and the mother of four children. She appears in the photo at FATEN's office.

Najah’s husband inherited a metal shop from his father and started running it fifteen years ago. He loves his work and would like to expand it and be able to serve more customers.

Najah thought of a loan from FATEN to help her husband meet his ambition as well as to increase their income to meet the living expenses of a big family.

Najah's husband wants to purchase a device that he will his use in his workshop to cut metal shapes. As Najah tells it, the workshop has been a profession in her husband’s family for years and has run very well since the day it started.

loans.use: To purchase a device for her husband to cut metal shapes

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: N. Christine est née en 1960 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Christine est mariée à ADJAGBE Michel, un pêcheur, et est mère de trois enfants, dont un reste à sa charge. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. Il y a environs 20 ans que Christine s'est installée au quartier Zogbo à Cotonou, où elle y vit avec son enfant à charge et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Christine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Depuis près de 30 ans, pour assurer ses différentes charges, Christine mène comme activité la vente de crevettes et de poissons fumés à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est au bord de la lagune que Christine s'approvisionne. Christine a déjà obtenu auprès de ALIDé, deux crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Christine souhaite renforcer son activité et satisfaire la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, ce qui lui permettra d'avoir plus de revenu. C'est ce qui amène Christine à solliciter un troisième prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Christine N. was born in 1960 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Michel ADJAGBE, a fisherman, and is mother to three children, one of whom is still under her care. Some of the children still attend school. About 20 years ago Christine settled in the Zogbo neighbourhood of Cotonou, where she now lives with her husband and the remaining child. She has not attended school herself. Both she and her husband share family expenses. For the past 30 years, Christine has met her various financial responsibilities by selling shrimp and smoked fish in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. She gets her supplies from the lakeshore. Christine has been granted two previous loans from ALIDé, both of which were duly repaid. She wants to strengthen her business and respond to the needs of an increasing number of customers, which will naturally increase her earnings. This is why she is now requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shrimp and fish

loans.name: Nasser

texts.en: Nasser is a 47-year-old married man with 4 unemployed children. He has been working as a taxi driver since 1990. He serves his village and its surroundings. He is well known by his customers, and sometimes he works on a private basis to earn extra profit for his family. Today, Nasser is requesting a loan of $1,200 to perform maintenance on his car after being in bad circumstances.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his car

loans.name: Simeona

texts.en:
Simeona B., age 59, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Danilo B., a businessman, and they are blessed with five offspring who already have families of their own. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own ornamental plant business for quite some time.

Simeona has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 5 times from CCT’s cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her plant business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business. She will use the loan funds to buy raw materials needed to produce her wares.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can have a good and comfortable life with her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Om

texts.en:
Mrs. Om D. is a humble villager who lives in Battambang Province. She is 38 years old and has established her own small family with other members. She is married to Savouth, age 48, who assists her in the business, and they help each other to care for two children who are students in the local public school. 

Om D. owns a simple shop next to her house where she sells different kinds of vegetables, for which she earns a profit. Om D. needs a loan to mend and decorate her old house because it is breaking down.

loans.use: To mend and decorate her old house

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali has worked in construction since 1994. He’s 28 years old and married, and has 3 young children who go to school. He started working in this occupation 16 years ago when he was very young. He works on a freelance basis and he's well known in this field with his long history. 

Ali is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy wood that he needs for his construction work.

loans.use: To buy wood

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.fr: D. Rosalie est née en 1964 à Abomey, une ville historique du Bénin. Mariée à SETANGNI Vincent, un mécanicien auto, Rosalie est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés, dont un est à sa charge. Il y a six ans environs que la famille s'est installée au quartier Zogbo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Rosalie a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au cours secondaire. Mais depuis près de 15 ans, pour contribuer à assurer les charges familiales, Rosalie vend des tissus de façon ambulante. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Rosalie s'approvisionne. La clientèle de Rosalie s'accroît au jour le jour, et Rosalie n'arrive plus à tous les satisfaire par manque de moyens financiers. Rosalie sollicite à cet effet, un crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue d'agrandir son activité et de mieux répondre aux besoins de ses clients.
texts.en:
Rosalie D. was born in 1964 in Abomey, a historic city in Benin. She is married to Vincent Setangni, a car mechanic, and is the mother of two children, both provided with schooling. One of them is in her care. About six years ago, the family settled in the Zogbo neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The parents provide together for their family. Rosalie attended school until secondary level. To help providing for their family, Rosalie has been hawking fabrics for nearly 15 years. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Her customer base grows day by day, and she is no longer able to meet the demand due to lack of funds. To this effect Rosalie came to Alidé and applied for a loan to expand her business and better meet the needs of her customers.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is 29 years old. She is married and has no children. Her husband is a businessman who supports their home. She sells underwear at retail prices to make a living. Before she got assistance from LAPO, she was a newspaper vendor. She used her LAPO loan as capital to start her business. 

Patience is hoping for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more underwear to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more underwear to sell

loans.name: Zeinelabidine

texts.en:
ZeinElAbdidine is a 30-year-old married man with 2 children. 

In 2006, he decided to open a new business after seeing a need for such services in the region. He bought a big electric motor to provide the region with electricity. During this period, his business productivity was automatically developed. 

Today, ZeinElAbidine is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase additional cables to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional cables

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana G., age 54, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Felicisimo G., a businessman, they are blessed with one child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own bakery for quite some time now.

Feliciana has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her bakery.

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business. She will use her loan to buy equipment and expand her bakery.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that they can renovate their house and finish educating their children.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment and expand her bakery

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther sells frozen foods, like chicken, turkey and frozen fish. She also has a business renting DVDs and VCDs. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family. 

Esther is married and has 2 children. She is 32 years old. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports the home. 

She is hoping for a loan of NGN 160,000 to purchase more frozen food to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders in anticipation of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen food to sell

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda E. is from the city of Tagoloan in Misamis Oriental. She is 63 years old. Esmeralda is widowed and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Esmeralda owns and operates a specialized retail store where she sells seafood, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Esmeralda has been engaged in her business for over 24 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Esmeralda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esmeralda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Esmeralda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Esmeralda's fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Germaine

texts.fr: D. A. P. Germaine est née le 26 Décembre 1958 et est mariée à GOMEZ Marcel, un frigoriste. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit au quartier Zogbo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Germaine vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les charges de la famille. Pour faire face à ses charges, Germaine mène comme activité, la vente de tissus et des mèches dans sa boutique size à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Germaine vend également des produits de la SOBEBRA (boissons) dans sa boutique, ce qui lui permet d'avoir plusieurs sources de revenu. Germaine s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé au Togo. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Germaine sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de la clientèle.
texts.en:
P. Germaine D. A. was born on December 26, 1958 and is married to Marcel Gomez, a refrigeration engineer. They have four children who all attend school. The family lives in the Zogbo neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Germaine helps her husband to provide for their family, in that she sells fabrics and hair extensions in her home-based store. Additionally, she sells drinks from the Beninese Brewing Company (Sobébra) in her store, which enables her to have several sources of income. Germaine gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and in Lomé (Togo). Since the demand of her customers keeps on increasing, Germaine came to Alidé and applied for a loan to boost her activity and better satisfy her customers' needs.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics and hair extensions

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary W. H. is twenty five years old. She is married to a driver and they hope to have children and raise them well. Her business is located in Thika, Kenya. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapple. 

Mary has a salon where she has been providing hair and beauty services to the local women for seven years. She has one employee who works very hard to ensure good service to the customers. She says that this business is profitable and her only major challenge is that there are many power blackouts slowing down her business operations. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more hair weaves and cosmetics to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to open many outlets and serve many more people, especially in different parts of the town. She is a very hardworking and honest lady.

loans.use: Hair weaves and cosmetics

loans.name: Rula

texts.en:
This is not the first loan that Rula has borrowed from FATEN. Our borrower is a housewife and the mother of 4 children. Her husband owns a shop in Beit Sahour, a small town in the Beth Lehem district, where he sells plastic items such as chairs, plates, cups, and small plastic cupboards. He also works in a small shop across from his own for a small salary.

The shop that Rula and her husband own, beside the salary he receives, comprise the family's entire income. Therefore, she applied for a loan to purchase more plastic items to sell in their small shop.

Rula says that she and her husband expect to improve their financial situation if the shop works as they are planning. This is not her first loan from FATEN and Rula is known for her commitment to repay on time.

In the picture, Rula is standing in her shop.

loans.use: To buy plastic items to sell

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en:
Fadi is a 46-year-old married man and father of 2 unemployed children. He has owned a car mechanic shop in his town since 1995. He has been involved in this occupation for the past 29 years. He repairs all type of cars and he's known in the whole region. 

With his long experience, Fadi is requesting a loan of $700 to repair his business tools, so his clients will request his services and he can meet their needs.

loans.use: To repair his business tools

loans.name: Anabell

texts.en:
Anabell sells electronics at the market in Lagos State. She has been in this business for 3 years. She hopes for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more electronics to sell. 

Anabell is 25 years old and married. She has no children, but she hopes to have children very soon. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports their home. She is a hardworking woman and she loves her business. She hopes to own an electronics company in the future. She says "thank you."

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Gracilyn

texts.en:
Gracilyn O., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Orlando O., a pipe fitter, and they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own meat and vegetable shop while supervising her computer shop.

Gracilyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 26,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business. by buying raw materials for her food business and additional stocks for her store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can send their children to college and finish a course.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchasing raw materials for food business and additional stocks for her store

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn L. is from the city of Tagoloan in Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Jocelyn's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is a married lady with two daughters. She runs a general store in Kikuyu. She has been in this business for four years. Her customers are mainly small scale retailers who buy for home consumption. Her husband, John, is also a businessman in Kikuyu, which is on the outskirts of Nairobi. 

Naomi was introduced to KADET by a friend and this will be her third loan. She had no previous credit history with other micro-finance institutions before joining Kadet. She wants to use the money from this loan to add more stock to her retail shop with things like detergent powders, bread, eggs, and much more.

She desires to see her shop grow into a leading wholesale shop in the area. This will improve their livings standards and she will be able to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: She plans to buy more stock for her shop

loans.name: Édith

texts.fr: M. Edith est née en 1972 à Dogbo au Mono. Edith vit depuis 20 ans environs au quartier Zogbo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Edith est mariée et mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Mais Edith vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule les différentes charges. Edith a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Edith mène comme activité la vente de riz, de chaussures et des produits cosmétiques à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo, que Edith se ravitaille. Edith exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d'année et a obtenu une fois déjà, de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Edith a bien remboursé le crédit. Edith sollicite un deuxième prêt afin de renforcer son capital et de rehausser le niveau de son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Édith M. was born in 1972 in Dogbo in the region of Mono. She has been living for about 20 years in the Zogbo neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married and the mother of four children who all attend school. Édith lives alone with her children and also provides alone for them. She studied until secondary level. Édith sells rice, shoes and cosmetics in her home-based store. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and in Lomé (Togo). She has been in this trade for ten years. Once she got a loan from Alidé which she repaid on schedule. This is Édith's second loan which she will use to strengthen her working capital and expand her business to better serve her customers.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, shoes and cosmetics

loans.name: Antony

texts.en:
Antony is a 28-year-old engaged man who lives with his parents and 2 siblings. His father has owned a seafood restaurant since 1985. Since 2005, Anthony has been handling the restaurant operation to help his father. His restaurant specializes by offering only seafood. It's located in a beautiful area overlooking the sea. His restaurant is really known for its delicious food and the beautiful view. 

Today, Antony is requesting a loan of $800 to buy music equipment, because he's planning to add entertainment to his restaurant for a good atmosphere.

loans.use: To buy music equipment

loans.name: Habel

texts.en:
Habel is a 30-year-old gentleman who is married to Lucy Wanjiru. They have a one-year-old baby. He has been operating in a "boda-boda" business (a bicycle with a padded rear seat for transporting passengers or light goods) in Naivasha since 2007.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to purchase a locally made, customized engine for his bicycle which will help him transport people and goods for longer distances without getting tired, hence increasing his income.

He plans to buy a motorcycle for his business, instead of a bicycle, which is more manual. This will increase his income because it will be faster to take people to their destinations and come back for more.

loans.use: To buy an engine for his bicycle

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle A. is from the city of Tagoloan in Misamis Oriental. She is 25 years old. Michelle is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Michelle sells personal products, such as cosmetics, in the local community. Michelle has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Michelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Michelle has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. Michelle is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Michelle's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a 29-year-old married woman with 2 children. In 2009, she opened a used clothing shop in her town to sell clothes at good prices. She opened her business after seeing a need for a place where customers could buy clothes for lower prices. She uses her business to help her husband to raise their two children. 

Today, Zainab is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy additional clothes. This will increase her sales and, therefore, her income.

loans.use: To buy additional clothes

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn C. is from the village of Balulang in Cagayan de Oro. She is 23 years old and single. To make a living, Analyn makes and sells snacks, such as lumpia (spring rolls), waffles, and other delicacies, in the local community. Analyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Analyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analyn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase the ingredients needed to make products to sell. This will be Analyn's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to make food to sell

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en: Khalil is a 20-year-old single man living with his parents. All the family cooperates together in the household. In 2007, Khalil opened a spare parts shop after 5 years of experience in this business. There is great demand for his spare parts thus he wants to buy more in order to fulfill his clients' requests. He wants to take out a loan of $1,000 to buy more spare parts and enlarge his shop to meet his clients' needs and earn a good income for his family.

loans.use: buy more spare parts

loans.name: Edralina

texts.en:
Edralina M., 34, is ensuring that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Noe M., a businessman, they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn an income so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her cosmetics direct selling business for quite some time now.

Edralina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 13,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital by buying equipment and expanding her business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can have a good and comfortable life with her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional stock

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is 41years old and married with five children. Her husband is an auto mechanic. She is a merchant who specializes in selling foodstuffs such as yams, plantains, tomatoes and peppers. She has been in this business for 7 years. She is an LAPO client. Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Juliana hopes for more progress in her business and to use her profits to improve her family’s standard of living. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Maria Lyn

texts.en:
Maria Lyn P. is from the village of Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 26 years old and married with 4 school-aged children. Maria Lyn owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Maria Lyn has been involved in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Maria Lyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Lyn is requesting her first loan from HSPFI, for 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Brigid

texts.en: Brigid K. K. is 48 years old and married with two children, 27 and 30 years old. His business is located at Makongeni, a busy market in Thika, the region in Kenya known for pineapple production. He has been selling watermelon for the last two years to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and his major challenge is an unsteady supply. However, he works very hard to keep his business going well. He is using his loan of KES 50,000 to buy more watermelon to expand his business. He hopes to have many business outlets and supply his cereals to different parts of the country in future. He is very innovative and wants to be a market leader in this business.

loans.use: to buy watermelon

loans.name: Angèle

texts.fr: A. Angèle est née vers 1965 à Zogbo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle réside depuis près de 30 ans.  Angèle est mariée à BONOU Ezéckiel, un pêcheur.  Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont à leur charge.   Angèle vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari.  Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille.  Angèle n’a jamais été à l’école.  Pour contribuer à supporter les charges familiales, Angèle prépare et vend des crevettes et des poissons fumés à Dantopka, marché international du Bénin.  Elle s’approvisionne au bord du fleuve.  Angèle exerce cette activité depuis 35 ans, et est à son troisième crédit à ALIDé.  Elle a bien remboursé les deux crédits antérieurs qu’elle avait obtenus et sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer son activité et acheter plus des crevettes et poissons.
texts.en:
Angèle A. was born around 1965 in the Zogbo neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, where she has been living for the past 30 years. She is married to Ézéchiel Bonou, a fisherman. They have four children, all provided with schooling, and two of them are in their care. The parents provide together for their family. Angèle never attended school. To help providing for the family, Angèle prepares and sells shrimps and smoked fish in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She gets her supplies at the river bank. Angèle has been in this business for 35 years. This is her third loan from Alidé. She repaid on schedule her previous two loans and applies now for another loan to boost her business and buy more shrimps and fish.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shrimps and fish

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith owns a fashion house where she offers tailoring services to her customers. She makes both Nigerian and western clothing designs for her customers. Faith also sells sarongs of various colors and shapes to her customers. She hopes to own a fashion school in the future where she will teach young boys and girls how to sew. 

She is married with six children. She is 40 years old and her husband is a farmer. Her children are still dependent on her and they attend school. Faith is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to add to her business capital so as to purchase more tailoring materials as well as sarongs to sell. She says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs

loans.name: Abir

texts.en: Abir is a 21-year-old single woman living with her family. After getting her technical certificate, she started working as a beautician and a hairdresser from her home in 2007. During those years, she has been able to accumulate a good number of clients and earn a good income. Today, because there are always new items and ideas in this market, Abir is asking to borrow $800 to purchase new and improved tools to increase her business and attract more customers.

loans.use: purchase new and improved tools

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia F. is from the village of Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 51 years old. Lydia is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Lydia owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $100 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Lydia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Lydia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Céline

texts.fr: A. Céline est née vers 1955 à Zogbo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle réside toujours.  Céline est une veuve et mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés.  Elle vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille.  Céline n’a jamais été à l’école.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Céline vend les produits divers et les condiments à son domicile.  C’est à Dantopka, marché international du Bénin, que Céline s’approvisionne.  Céline a 30 ans d’expérience dans l’exercice de cette activité.  Céline a bénéficié antérieurement de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Elle voudrait renforcer le stock de ses produits.  C’est pour ça qu’elle sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Céline A. was born around 1955 in the Zogbo neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, where she still lives. She is a widow and the mother of four children, all provided with schooling. Céline lives alone with her children and provides alone for them. She never attended school. To provide for her needs, Céline sells various products and condiments in her home-based store. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She has an experience of 30 years' standing in this activity. So far Céline benefitted from two loans from Alidé which she repaid on schedule. She would like to expand her inventory. This is why she came to Alidé and applied for a third loan.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products and condiments

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda S. is from the village of Balulang, Cagayan de oro City. She is 40 years old. Gilda is married and has ten adult-aged children. To make a living, Gilda owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Gilda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $75 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Gilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Gilda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in her business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in her business

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Florentine

texts.fr: T. Florentine est née vers 1978 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Florentine vit au quartier Zogbo à Cotonou depuis 10 ans.  Mariée à KESSIWEDE Marc, un revendeur, Florentine est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés.  Florentine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari.  Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille.  Florentine n’a jamais été à l’école.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Florentine vend les condiments et les oignons à son domicile.  C’est à Dantopka, marché international du Bénin, que Florentine s’approvisionne.  Florentine a 10 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine. Elle a bénéficié antérieurement de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Elle voudrait renforcer le stock de ses produits et acheter d’oignons et des tomates.  C’est pour ça que  Florentine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Florentine T. was born around 1978 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been living in the Zogbo neighborhood of Cotonou for the past ten years. Married to Marc KESSIWEDE, a reseller of goods, Florentine is the mother of two children, both in school. She lives with her children and husband, shares family expenses with her husband, and has never attended school herself. To meet her needs, Florentine sells condiments and onions from her home. She restocks in Benin’s international market, Dantokpa. She has accumulated 10 years of experience in this business. She was granted two previous loans from ALIDé, both repaid in full. She wants to increase her stock of supplies and buy onions and tomatoes. That is why she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: But onions and tomatoes

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a restaurateur with over five years' experience in the sale of cooked foods and drinks. She hopes to grow her business into a world-class restaurant.  She is 32 years old, married, and has four children. Her husband is a commercial motorcyclist and he also supports the home. She is requesting the sum of 50,000 NGN to purchase a refrigerator to enable her to sell cold drinks to her customers. She says this will boost her business and attract more customers. She hopes for an increase in her business and for the best in life for her family. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator

loans.name: Wissam

texts.en: Wissam is a married woman, 43 years old, and she is the mother of four children. She has been working as a tailor since 1987. She cooperates with her family in the household to provide a better quality of life. She repairs clothes and she tailors clothing and wedding robes, etc. Today, Wissam is asking to borrow $1,200 to buy merchandise such as textiles, threads, needles, etc. in order to meet the requirements of her clients.

loans.use: buy merchandise such as textiles, threads, needles

loans.name: Najebullah

texts.en:
Najebullah son of G. N. is educated and is a married man. He has worked in a butcher shop for more than ten years. He is a hard-working man. He has requested an individual loan of 50,000 AFN to complete his various stocks of meat and to buy some necessary things to help in his business in order to build a better future for his children and family. 

He would like to thank everyone who supports him and hopes to continue his partnership with both Kiva and AFS in the coming years.

loans.use: to buy necessary things for his butcher shop

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou M. is from the village of Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 44 years old. Marilou is married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Marilou owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $100 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Marilou is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Rose

texts.fr: Née le 12 janvier 1972 à Porto Novo, capitale administrative et politique du Bénin, A. Rose réside au quartier Zogbo à Cotonou depuis 18 ans.  Rose est mariée à GOUSSANGNI Sosthène, un menuisier, et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés.  Rose vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Rose n’a jamais été à l’école.  Pour contribuer  à supporter les charges familiales, Rose vend de l’alcool, l’huile végétale, et boisson « Sodabi » (boisson alcoolisée locale) à son domicile et par le système de distribution.  Rose a 10 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine. Elle a bénéficié antérieurement de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Rose voudrait renforcer le stock de ses produits et acheter des bidons contenant l’huile et de la boisson « Sodabi ».  C’est pour ça que Rose sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born January 12, 1972 in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of Benin, Rose A. has been living in the Zogbo neighborhood of Cotonou for the past 18 years. Rose is married to Sosthène GOUSSANGNI, a carpenter, and is the mother of three children, all attending school. She has never been to school herself. She lives together with her children and husband, with whom she shares family expenses. To assist in meeting expenses, Rose sells alcohol, vegetable oil, and “Sodabi” drink (a local alcoholic beverage), both from her home and as an itinerant vendor. Rose has ten years’ experience doing this. She was granted two previous loans from ALIDé, reimbursed in full. Rose now wants to increase her stock supply and buy containers of vegetable oil and cases of “Sodabi”. This is why she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy containers of vegetable oil and cases of “Sodabi” drink

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is 39 years old and she is married with four children. She is carrying her youngest child on her back in the picture. Her husband is a commercial driver, and he also supports the home. She is a LAPO client. The "Lift Above Poverty Organization" is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Evelyn sells foodstuffs like tubers of yam and garri (cassava flakes) at retail prices to her customers. She is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to improve her family’s standard of living. She duly thanks all Kiva lenders in anticipation of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana S. is from the village of  Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 50 years old. Susana is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business buying and selling bananas and root crops like cassava and sweet potatoes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $125 a month from this activity.

In 2010, Susana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en: Maribel C. is from the village of Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 46 years old. Maribel is widowed and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Maribel sells vegetables in the local community. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Maribel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Maribel from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is 42 years old and married with six children. Her husband is a retired civil servant. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy. 

She is a trader who sells fruits and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She uses her experience in business to attract and retain her customers. She is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more fruits and foodstuffs to sell. She has a good relationship with LAPO, a Kiva partner. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Emmah

texts.en:
Emmah W. M. is 42 years old and married. She has two children, aged 13 and 5. Her business is located at the mountain view estate in Thika, Kenya. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. 

She has been selling such items as detergents, soft drinks, paraffin and others for the last five years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is there are so many people doing the same kind of business as hers in the area and so customers are spoiled for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more general items to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. She is very hardworking and honest and loves cooking.

loans.use: Soft drinks, detergents and other household items

loans.name: United People Club Group

texts.en: Angeline F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United People Club. She is 35 years old and married. She has four children, who are 2 months old and 13, 16 and 19 years old. In addition to her children, Angeline also supports her grandmother. For eight years, Angeline has been selling rice and soup at the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She keeps her stall clean and provides good food, which keeps customers returning. Angeline plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more meat for the soup. Her goal is to grow her business and to have all of her children attend school. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Angeline is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more meat for soup

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence sells groceries and foodstuffs at retail prices. She is 46 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Her eldest child is 20 years old. Her children attend school and during the holidays and weekends, they assist her with sales. 

She has been in this business for 11 years. She hopes to expand her business and attract more customers. She is requesting a loan amount of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Soan

texts.en: Soan C. is from the village of Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 19 years old. Soan is single. To make a living, Soan operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling processed food like pork tocino, longganiza and chorizo in the local community. Soan has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Soan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Soan is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Soan from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
