About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is married to Philip, and they have a five-year-old child. They live in Kikuyu, a peri-urban town which has a great deal of business potential. Nancy runs a retail shop, selling goods including juices, biscuits, chocolates and sweets to a steady network of customers who live within her area of business. She also supplies her goods to other retail shops.

Nancy has never borrowed from other institutions apart from KADET, which she was introduced to by her friends, and this will be her third loan with which she will add more stocks of the chocolates and sweets in her shop. Nancy plans to expand her trade in order to supply to a wider area and thus increase her daily sales.

loans.use: Nancy plans to add more boxes of chocolates and other sweets.

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en:
Nadia is a wife and mother of four children in Beit Sahour\ Beth Lehem district and runs, together with her husband, a Shawerma (sandwich-like wrap of shaved grilled lamb and chicken) food stall. Three of her sons are married while her daughter is still living with her parents. 

One of the three sons, his wife and two children live with Nadia and her husband; this son is employed and helps his family financially.

Nadia is taking a US$ 3000 loan from FATEN to buy a new Shawerma-making device they need to improve their food stall. They dream of increasing its size and improving it.

Nadia, who appears in the picture above, is one of our long-term committed borrowers.

loans.use: Purchasing a Shawerma-making device

loans.name: Jamileh

texts.en: Jamileh has worked as a home-based hairdresser and beautician for the past 10 years. She is married with three unemployed children. She cooperates with her husband to offer a comfortable life for her children. Today, Jamileh is asking for her second loan of $1,000 because she's planning to develop her business by buying new hairdresser tools and supplies to earn additional profit.

loans.use: Buying new hairdresser tools and supplies

loans.name: Aby

texts.fr: Madame Aby S. est une femme mariée âgée de 48 ans. Mère d’un enfant de 16 ans, elle est femme de charge à la garderie du PDEF (Programme de développement des enfants et Familles), un programme du Child Fund ex Christian Child Fund (CCF). Madame S. pratique en parallèle le commerce, une activité qu’elle a copiée sur ses parents commerçants. Cependant pour renforcer son activité, elle vient solliciter pour la première fois un crédit de 100 000 FCFA. Elle compte acheter avec ce montant des chaussures qu’elle va revendre à ses clients.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aby S. is a 48-year-old woman, mother of a 16-year-old child. She is a housekeeper at the PDEF Nursery (Development Program for Children and Families), a program of Child Fund, ex-Christian Child Fund (CCF). Mrs. S. has another activity selling goods, which was inspired by her parents’ own commercial activities. To strengthen her business, she is requesting for the first time a loan for 100,000 FCFA, with which she will buy shoewear for resale to her customers.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes

loans.name: Ebenezer #5 Group

texts.en: Samuel P. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Ebenezer #5. He is 31 years old, single and a university student. He has one child who is 13 years old and attends 6th grade. For six years, Samuel has had a calling-card business on Broad Street in downtown Monrovia. He says that he manages his business well, which attracts customers. Samuel plans to use his 10,400 Liberian dollar portion of this 46,600 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more calling cards. His goal is to have a shop, send his child to school and have good health care. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Samuel is the one holding the sign. This is his group's second time on Kiva; the first time they were posted (http://www.kiva.org/lend/142166), Samuel's name was listed in error as Emmanuel. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more calling cards

loans.name: Burikhon

texts.ru: Нурматов Бурихон проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 24 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Он живет вместе с радителями. Брат, строитель а отец занимается растениеводством. Сам Бурихон более 5 лет занимается животноводством. Он разводит скот. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота. Бурихон хочет купить молодого бычка и увеличить количество скота.
texts.en:
Burikhon N. lives in the area of Javan. He is twenty-four, married and has two children. His wife is a homemaker and they live together with his parents. His brother is in construction and father is in agriculture. Burihon has raised cattle for more than five years. He is asking for a loan to purchase additional cattle. Burihon would like to buy a young bull for breeding and increase the number of his cattle.

Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel P., 24, just joined ASHI in 2009. Her early marriage and motherhood pushed her capabilities in running a small business. She had no other way to change her life, as well as her two children’s lives, as she depended on her husband’s small income as a motorcycle technician. She is not even a graduate of college (because she came from a poor family) to be employed in offices or have a better paying job. Because of that, Maricel opened her eyes to see more options for having her own income; hence, she thought of her skill in cooking food. She thought that maybe, selling food as her business would provide her an income which she could use to augment her husband’s. 

When she became a member of ASHI, the loan she received was used to start her envisioned business. She gained a lot of customers from the neighborhood and even from other villages. After six months, she had fully repaid her loan and had improved their life a little. Her second loan, with a much larger amount, enhanced further her business; however, to fully achieve her dream of having a restaurant, she needs more loans. Therefore, after just recently paying off her second loan, Maricel is again requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos. This will be used for the same purpose. Some of the proceeds of her business will be spent for obtaining her family’s basic needs, while some will be saved for her two children, whose ages are 2 and 5.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase utensils and ingredients for cooking food to sell

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en: Ghassan is a 37 year old married man and father of 2 young children. Since 2005, he has owned an orange trolley which he uses to travel around his town and its surroundings. He offers all types of orange juice. Today, Ghassan is requesting $1,000 to buy a large number of oranges at a good price in order to expand his business productivity.

loans.use: To buy a large number of oranges.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane W. M. is twenty-four years old, married and has one child aged six years old. Her business is located at Gachororo in Thika, Kenya. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. She has been selling such items as rice, sugar, soft drinks, flour and others for the last two years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is the fluctuation of prices in the market, making her sell her products at low prices. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more rice, sugar, and flour to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. She is a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, flour and other items.

loans.name: Ndeye Déguène

texts.fr: Madame Ndeye Déguène D. est enseignante mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle s’active également depuis un an dans le commerce de parfums et tissus sous l’influence de ses copines qui la ravitaillaient en marchandises  pendant les vacances. Membre d’U-IMCEC depuis presque 2 ans, Madame D. souhaite un financement de 300 000 FCFA  pour renforcer son activité devenue de plus en plus fructueuse. Elle pourra ainsi avec ce crédit acheter quelques tissus et des parfums.
texts.en:
Mrs Ndeye Déguène D. is a teacher by profession, and a married mother of three. A year ago she also started selling perfume and fabric, thanks to her friends who ensure her inventory is well-stocked over the holidays. Mrs D. has been a member of the U-IMCEC for nearly two years, and is seeking a loan of 300 000 FCFA in order to bolster her increasingly profitable business. She will be able to use to credit to buy a variety of fabrics and perfumes.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabric and perfume

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios V. is a typical mother who dreams of her children having a better life someday - a life that is not like what they have right now, which is very poor. She wants her children to experience happiness which she did not experience when she was young because her parents were poor and making friends and socializing was never in the list of her choices. 

Since 1996, when Remedios became a member of ASHI, she found her strength and courage to face the challenges brought about by poverty. Loans she requested and received were used for a fishing business in partnership with her husband. Eventually it went well and her proceeds were used to finance the education of her three children, whereby the 28 year old eldest child is now a teacher and the other two are in college. However, Remedios wants to buy their own motor fishing boat instead of buying fish from others in their village. Even though this activity will be pursued, Remedios wants it to grow, therefore, she is requesting a much larger amount of loan through the ASHI and KIVA partnership. This loan is very significant for her because the graduation of her two children from college relies on her business profit.

loans.use: To finance a fishing business.

loans.name: Petty Trader Group

texts.en:
James K. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Petty Traders. He is married, and has five children who are 16, 18, 19, 21 and 28 years old. 

For over 26 years, James has had a dry goods business at the Rally Town Market. James sells quality goods in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.  

James plans to use his 4,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 20,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more dry goods such as locks, nails and rope.  His goal is to grow his business and to provide a good future for his children.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, James is the one holding the sign. Tamba S. is inset at lower left.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts an emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more goods such as locks, nails and ropes.

loans.name: Ka-La-Mayre Group

texts.en:
Pictured above are members of the Ka-La-Mayre group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. The leader of the group is Jatu S..  She has been a businesswoman for 3 years now. Jatu sells firewood and local produce like palm oil, groundnuts, rice, etc.  She is 30 years of age. Her husband is a businessman. Jatu has 2 children, all of whom are in primary schools. She was born in Sanda. Jatu will use this loan to purchase firewood, and local produce.

The members of this group are all local entrepreneurs in Makump village. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva Lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profits and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase firewood, palm oil, and rice.

loans.name: One Word Camp Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the One Word Camp. The leader of the group is Safie S. (left). The 35 year old Safie was born in Kono, eastern Sierra Leone. A married woman and with 2 children, 1 in primary school and 1 in secondary school, Safie has sold briefcases, clothes, dishes, etc. for 2 years. Safie will use her share of the loan to further expand her business. She will use it to buy the above mentioned items in large quantities. 

Members of the One Word Camp are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni city. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs will be accessing from SMT/Kiva Lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit, and consequently improve their living standards by sending their children to school, feeding themselves and their children, buying clothing, etc.

loans.use: To buy briefcases, clothes, dishes, etc.

loans.name: Serreh Group

texts.en:
Pictured above are members of the Serreh Group. The leader of the group is Mariama J.. The 38 year old Mariama was born in neighboring Guinea. She is married to a motor-mechanic and they have 3 children attending secondary school. Mariama has sold “gara lappers” (locally dyed clothes) for more than 20 years now. She will use her share of the loan to further expand her business. She will buy materials for making gara lappers like ink, caustic soda, powder, white cottons, etc.  

Members of the Serreh Group are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni city. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs will be accessing from SMT/Kiva Lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit, and consequently improve their living standards by sending their children to school, feeding themselves and their children, buying clothing, etc.

loans.use: To buy materials for making gara lappers like ink, caustic soda, powder, white cottons, etc

loans.name: To-Kuru Omarsu Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the To-Kuru Omarsu Group (in Temne: May God Help Us). The leader of the group is Aminata C.. She has been a businesswoman for many years now. The 45-year-old Aminata sells shoes. She is married to a farmer and they have 3 children, one of whom is already married, one is in secondary school, and the other is a businessman. Aminata was born in a place call Konsho, in northern Sierra Leone. She will use this loan to further expand on her business. She will use it to buy dozens of shoes to add to her current stock. 

Members of the To-Kuru Omarsu group are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni city.  This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs will be accessing from SMT/Kiva Lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit, and consequently improve their living standards by sending their children to school, feeding themselves and their children, buying clothing, etc.

loans.use: Buy dozens of shoes

loans.name: Na We Cam Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the 'Na We Cam' Group. The leader of the group is Alaymatu K.. She has been a businesswoman for many years now. Alaymatu sells bars of soap and cakes. She is 35 years of age. She is married to a professional worker and they have 4 children, all of whom are in primary school. Alaymatu was born in Makeni. She will use this loan to further expand her business. She will use it to buy soap and cake-making materials. 

Members of the 'Na We Cam' group are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni city.  This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs will be accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit, and consequently improve their living standards by sending their children to school, feeding themselves and their children, buying clothing, etc.

loans.use: Buy soap and cake-making materials

loans.name: Hands And Minds Group

texts.en:
Anna D. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'Hands and Minds'. She is 59 years old and is married, with 8 children aged 20 -38 years old. Their educational levels are high school graduates-university graduates. She also cares for 7 orphans. She is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to poverty.

Anna and her family live and work in the Cotton Tree community in Harbel, Margibi county, Liberia. Her business is the sale of fish. She buys from fishermen wholesale and sells retail to residents of her community in Harbel. She has been running this business for more than 20 years and hopes to re-establish her cold storage business that got destroyed during the Liberia Civil crisis.

Anna started by selling doughnuts, then she later got into used clothes sales, and finally decided to sell fish. She determines the kinds of fish customers like to buy and brings more of that in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.

Anna needs this loan to purchase more fish for resale to improve her business. She dreams of her children continuing to the highest level of education in the future. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Anna is the lady standing in the right side of the photo.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale to improve business.

loans.name: Friday

texts.en: Friday is a commercial driver. He is 60 years old and married with 3 children. His children are attending school and they are doing well. His wife is a merchant and she also supports the home. He has been a commercial driver for 15 years. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes for a bigger and better business in the future in order to improve his family’s standard of living. He is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to overhaul his car that he uses for commercial purposes. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To overhaul his car

loans.name: Kankalay Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Kankalay Group. The leader of the group is Salamatu K.. She has been a businesswoman for many years now. Salamatu sells charcoal, rice, groundnuts, and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). She is 45 years of age. Salamatu has 3 children, 2 of whom are in primary school and 1 in secondary school. She was born in Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. Salamatu will use this loan to further expand her business. She will use it to buy charcoal, rice, groundnuts and palm oil.

Members of the Kankalay group are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni city.  This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs will be accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit, and consequently improve their living standards.

loans.use: Buy charcoal, rice, groundnut and palm oil

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr: Monsieur Ibrahima N. est un jeune célibataire photographe qui vient de régler dans sa totalité le prêt qu’il avait contracté, il y’a un an. Pour un  besoin urgent, Monsieur N. sollicite un prêt de 80 000 FCFA pour profiter d’un achat complémentaire de matériels à bon marché. Il compte s’acquérir d’un appareil et graveur pour pouvoir assurer ses montages afin de tenir correctement ses reportages dans les cérémonies et renforcer son business. Ce photographe d’une  expérience de 19 ans enseigne également la langue arabe en plus des cours de photographe qu’il donne.
texts.en:
Mr Ibrahima N. is a young, single photographer who has just completely repaid the loan that he received a year ago. He is urgently seeking an 80 000 FCFA loan in order to benefit from a reasonably priced order for materials. He is looking to buy a camera and a wood etcher for his montages in order to accurately portray his photo-reportages and to bolster his business. This photographer with 19 years´experience also teaches Arabic alongside the photography course that he holds.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Photographic equipment

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Naomi is a 41-year-old business lady who operates a printing business in Nairobi. She has been in this business for 10 years and was a housewife previously. She also trades in shares and supplies stationery to earn extra income. She has requested a loan of Kes. 80,000 to buy a printing machine. She says that since joining Faulu, she bought a printing machine which attracted more customers due to improved output. She hopes to own a bigger company with more employees and own a home. She describes herself as saved, hard-working and reliable.

loans.use: To buy a printing machine

loans.name: Imane

texts.en: Imane is a 27-year-old divorced woman living alone. She has been working as a private teacher for the past 10 years. She works hard to provide herself better living conditions, especially after her divorce. Today, Imane is requesting to borrow US$ 800 to buy a computer that will facilitate her work preparation and research for the students.

loans.use: buy a computer

loans.name: Shokirdjon

texts.en:
Shokirdjon is a responsible family man and father who cares for his family with great attention. He comes from an agricultural family and today it is these activities which provide a major source of income which allows him to support his 5 children. Shokirdjon has a friendly family who always try to help each other. His dream is to see his sons succeed, and it is in order to achieve this that his efforts know no limit. In this case, his wish is to improve his seeding and to care for his animals, for which Shokirdjon needs a loan. Your help is very important for this hard-working and humble worker.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Cotton Tree United Group

texts.en:
Evelyn S. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called Cotton Tree United. She is 31 years old and is married with 3 children, aged 1 year 6 months to 11 years old. Their educational levels are kindergarten  to 5th grade. She also cares for 2 nephews and a niece. She could not go to school herself because her guardians refused to educate her hence her parents could not afford to raise her.

Evelyn and her family live in the Cotton Tree community and she does her selling in the Harbel market, Margibi county, Liberia. Her business is fish sales. She buys her fish from fishermen wholesale and sells retail on a table to residents of Harbel.

She has been running this business for 12 years and hopes to own a store in the near future. Evelyn started selling with 1500 Liberian Dollars given to her by her husband as working capital; she now operates with 20,000 as her working capital. She talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her. 

Evelyn needs this loan to purchase additional fish for resale to increase her profit. She dreams of educating her children and changing their living standard.



In the photo that accompanies this profile, Evelyn is the lady standing in the right of the photo wearing a white T-shirt.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish for resale to increase her profit

loans.name: Silas

texts.en: Silas is 34 years old, married and has three children, all of whom are in school. For the last eight years, he has run a shop where he sells flour, sugar, salt and other food items. He also runs a taxi service and a farm. He has one employee, and is very grateful to Faulu Kenya for helping him provide for his family, and especially for helping him give his children an education.  He would like his children to continue in school, and expand his businesses by buying a piece of land on which he can build rental housing. Silas has requested a loan of Kes. 60,000 to buy supplies for his store, including sugar, kerosene and maize.  He is hardworking and friendly, and would also like to open a wholesale business in the future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, kerosene and maize to sell in his store

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben O. is 60 years old and lives in the town of Emuhaya in the Vihiga district. He is married to Agnes O. and they have five children, all of whom have graduated from high school except their youngest, who is eight years old.

For the last 34 years, he has operated a store in the town market. Having repaid a previous loan from our organization, Kadet Ltd., he has applied for a new one to buy more items to sell, including sugar, fat, tissue paper, soaps and soft drinks. His customers live in the surrounding community or go to local schools.

In the future, Reuben hopes to establish a milk-processing business whose profits will allow him to send his children to college.

loans.use: to buy sugar, cooking fat, tissue and others items to sell to his customers

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en: Since 2005, Fadi has made a living working as a DJ at ceremonies, weddings and speciA. events. Before going into business for himself, he had 10 years of experience in this field. He is 36 years old, married and really likes his job because he loves playing music all the time. Fadi has applied for a loan for $1,000 to buy new equipment, including recording devices, to expand his business by working at events during the coming summer season.

loans.use: to buy new equipment, including recording devices

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Madame Awa S. âgée de 36 ans est une femme divorcée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle vend des tissus, parfums, laits de toilette, de la pâte d’arachide et de l’huile de palme depuis 6 ans après son divorce. Membre d’U-IMCEC depuis 2008, Madame S. y sollicite pour la première fois un crédit de 200 000 FCFA pour renforcer son activité. Ainsi avec ce prêt, Madame Awa S. compte s’approvisionner en tissus et parfums qu'elle va placer à ses clients.
texts.en:
Mrs Awa S. is a 36 year-old divorced mother of two. She has been making a living by selling fabric, perfume, toilet water, peanut butter and palm oil since her divorce six years ago. She has been a member of U-IMCEC since 2008, and this 200 000 FCFA loan to bolster her business is the first that she has requested. Mrs Awa S. aims to use this loan to source fabric and perfume for her clients.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sourcing fabric and perfume

loans.name: God's Mercy Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth V. leads a group of five borrowers called God’s Mercy. She is 42 years old, married, and has three children who are 18, 19 and 23 years old. In addition to her children, Elizabeth also supports three of her nieces.

For 15 years, Elizabeth has made a living selling cocoa nuts and fish at the Red Light Market, the largest market in Liberia.  She sells the cocoa nuts wholesale by the bag and the fish individually, which is convenient for customers and keeps them coming back to make new purchases.

Elizabeth plans to use her 9,000 Liberian-dollar portion of this 45,000 Liberian-dollar group loan to buy more cocoa nuts and fish.  Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children and her nieces.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Elizabeth is the one holding the sign. The inset at the right is a photo of loan group member Mamie K..

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts a special emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more fish and cocoa nuts.

loans.name: Oqtay

texts.en: Oqtay S. is 53 years old and works as a merchant selling building materials in his home village of Agsu city. He is married and has three children. Oqtay started his business eight years ago and owing to his easygoing character and friendly attitude toward customers, he gained respect and a wide clientele. Oqtay would like to expand his business and for this purpose he applied for a loan amounting to 1600 AZN. You can be an important part of this hard-working man's business.

loans.use: purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Oisulov

texts.en:
I. Oisulov is 48 years old, married, has three children, and makes a living selling children's toys. She sells these items in a store she rents in a local market. Oisulov has run this business for five years, and has done well in part because she does not have many competitors. She has always dreamed of owning her own small store and not having to depend on anyone else. She believes that someday this will happen, but for now has  requested a loan for $1,500 to buy new goods to sell to her customers. Oisulov thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to repay this loan fully and on time. Let’s get behind this dedicated mother and make her dream come true.   
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which began soon after independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

loans.use: To buy new children's toys to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Emiliana

texts.en: Emiliana D. is from the village of Daanglungsod. She is 62 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Emiliana owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2007, Emiliana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Emiliana is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a printing machine

loans.name: Khudoidod

texts.en: K. Khudoidod is married and has seven children. He has always been a hard-working man who has made sure, from a young age, that his family never goes without their daily bread. Khudoidod has a grocery store where he sells different kinds of foodstuffs. With a starting capital of $100 USD, thanks to his perseverance and dedication, he began this enterprise four years ago. Over time he expanded his business and today this business has become domestic as his children and wife are also engaged in it. Today Khudoidod needs to buy additional foodstuffs to increase the range of his selling goods. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting a loan of 1,250 USD. He is ready to work even harder, to make sacrifices, and to push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe Khudoidod’s perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business. loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to increase the range of his goods

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 44-year-old married man with five unemployed children who still go to school.

Ali has been working as a builder since 1990. He takes on home projects upon request of his clients and works through other entrepreneurs. He works hard to satisfy the heavy family needs.

Today, Ali is requesting $1,000 to buy a concrete mixer track to increase his work productivity.

loans.use: To buy a concrete mixer track

loans.name: Sharofat

texts.en: Y. Sharofat is 47 years old and has sold foodstuffs in her grocery for more than five years. She began her business as a street vendor near the local school of her community. Over time she expanded her business and now she has a grocery store where she sells her goods. Weekly Sharofat travels to the neighboring town for purchasing new goods. Currently she is requesting a loan of 13,000 Somoni for purchasing foodstuffs to expand her business. Sharofat sincerely thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to be accurate with the loan repayment. loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to increase her range of goods

loans.name: Happy

texts.en: Happy is 28 years old. She is married with two children and her husband is a businessman. Happy is a lovely woman. She attracts happiness to her business and this has made her attract and retain more customers. She sells foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to expand her business. Happy has a good relationship with LAPO. (Lift Above Poverty Organization)  LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Rano

texts.ru: Хайдарова Рано проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 31 год. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Муж на заработках в России. Рано более 5 лет торгует на рынке. Она в основном продает метровую плиенку. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота. Рано на полученные деньги хочет увеличить ассортимент своего товара, чтобы привлечь внимание клиентов.
texts.en:
Rano K. lives in Tursunzoda. She is thirty-one years old, married and has two children. Her husband works abroad in Russia. She has been working at the local market for over five years. She mainly sells plastic packaging wrap. She is asking for a loan to increase her sales. She will use the funds to increase her product variety to attract more customers.

Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more oil, rice and flour.

loans.name: Islam

texts.en: Islam M. is 40 years old and works as an entrepreneur who sells different kinds of  domestic goods. He has eleven years of experience in this field. Islam is married and has three sons who are the meaning of his life. Islam wishes one day that they will become educated and independent adults. Islam applied for a loan amounting to 1600 AZN to purchase more items to sell.

loans.use: purchase more merchandise to increase profit

loans.name: God Is In Control Group

texts.en:
Roland G. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is in Control. He is 33 years old and single. He has a two-year-old child whose educational level is nursery school. Roland is a high school graduate but he could not continue his education through university due to poverty. Roland and his family live and work in Dolo’s town, Harbel, Margibi County, Liberia. His business is the sale of gasoline.  He buys his products from wholesalers and sells at retail per gallon to residents of Dolo’s town, Harbel, Margibi County, Liberia.
 
He has been running this business for more than five years and hopes to own a petroleum station in the near future. Roland started selling gasoline with 980 Liberian Dollars that was given to him as working capital; he now operates with 45,000 Liberian Dollars.  He talks to his customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from him. Roland needs this loan to purchase more gasoline for resale to improve business.
He dreams of giving his daughter the best education to have a good future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Roland is the fellow standing on the right, wearing light blue shirt.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more gasoline for resale.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is 29 years old and sells used caps and socks. He has been in the business for six years and his wife assists him. Previously, he was selling used clothes. He contributes his money in a merry-go-round (a local loan system) which helps him save his money.

Simon feels that since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to improve his business and support his family. He has requested KES 20,000 to add to his stock of caps.

Simon hopes to own a house and have a big business so as to support his family and invest. He sees himself having a stable business in the future. He describes himself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To add to his stock of caps

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Korto United Group

texts.en: Korto K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Korto United. She is 29 years old and is married with three children, 3 to 11 years old, with educational levels of nursery through 3rd grade. Korto could not continue her education past 3rd grade due to illness. Korto and her family live and work in the Cotton Tree community in Harbel, Margibi County in Liberia. In the photo, Korto is the one standing on the right. For eight years, Korto has been selling roasted meat. She buys raw meat by the pound, cooks it and sells it per piece to residents of her community. She sells good quality meat, which encourages customers to continue buying from her. Korto plans to use her 4,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 20,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more meat. She dreams of being able to keep her children in school. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more meat to roast and sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 40-year-old married man and has three children. He has worked since 1998 in selling curtains and tablecloths. He started this kind of job after seeing a need for such services in the region and by working on a traveling basis he easily reaches his clients.

Today, Mohamad is asking to borrow $1,200 to buy more inventory so as to continue to cater to his clientele and make a good income.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Tuichibek

texts.en: M. Tuichibek is 29 years old and lives with his wife and two children. For the past three years Tuichibek has been farming, planting potatoes, onions and corn which he grows to sell as well as for his own family consumption. Every day he tends to his fields. In the case of corn, Tuichibek dries it and later threshes it, puts it in sacks and stores it for future sales. The process for planting his fields is first to prepare them with organic fertilizer. Later, using his plough, he sows them and afterwards is the period when he irrigates and applies fertilizer and insecticides, if necessary. All this is to insure a good harvest. Tuichibek will invest the loan in the purchase of organic fertilizers to prepare his land to raise potatoes and other crops. loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married. She sells women's clothing at Yulana market in Pavlograd town and her income is about 5,000 UAH per month.

Natalya started her own business thirteen years ago. A small salary that was not paid on time forced her to think of having her own business. She began to sell women's clothing and her business began to grow. Recently she opened a second location. She is glad she can increase her turnover as well as give a job to someone who needs it.

Natalya would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to purchase seasonal inventory. She hopes to receive additional income and take better care of her family.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal inventory

loans.name: God Bless You Club #1 Group

texts.en:
Fatu J. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Bless You Club #1. She is 46 years old and is married. She has three children between the ages of nine and 25 - their educational levels are between the third and the eleventh grade. She also cares for some siblings. She is a high school graduate but could not continue her education due to poverty.

Fatu and her family live and work on Benson Street, opposite the A.M.E. Zion University in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. Fatu’s business is the sale of food such as cooked rice, and drinks such as soft drinks and alcoholic beverages. She buys her food and drink items and sells them in a shop to residents in the Monrovia community. She has been running this business for 18 years and hopes to expand it to such a level that she would be able to own a restaurant in the near future.

Fatu started her business with 150 Liberian dollars as working capital, and she now operates with 100,000 Liberian dollars as working capital. She sells high-quality food in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her. Fatu needs this loan in order to purchase more food to serve her customers.  She dreams of getting a house of her own.

In the photo, Fatu is the one holding the sign. Nyenpu Y. is inset at the bottom right of the photo.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more food and drinks for sale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 36 years old, widowed, and takes care of three children. She has been operating a retail shop in Naivasha town since 2006. She sells things like toothpaste, bar soaps, sugar, and rice.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to buy more goods to sell, including dry foodstuffs, maize, sugar, and rice.

In the future, she hopes to grow her business into a wholesale outlet.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell in her retail shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more rice and oil for sale

loans.name: Mahfirat

texts.ru: Разокова Махфират проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 26 лет. Вдова, имеет 2 детей. Махфират живет вместе с родителями. Она более 5 лет занимаентся торговлей на рынке. Махфират в основном продает обувь. Этот бизней ей приносит доход. Она одна содержит семью. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Mahfirat R. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. She is 26 years old, a widow and has 2 children. Mahfirat lives with her parents. She has been involved in retail sales at the market for over 5 years. Mahfirat mainly sells shoes. This business brings her profit. She is the sole provider for her family. She is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Nidal

texts.en:
Nidal has owned an aluminum shop since 1995. He is a 45-year-old married man and has four children. He makes all aluminum products and he's very well known in this field by his customers. He's thankful for his work because he's able to meet his children's needs and to pay for their schooling. 

Today, Nidal is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy new tools needed to continue his work properly and satisfy the demands of the market.

loans.use: To buy new tools

loans.name: Abdugafur

texts.en:
B. Abdugafur has been selling women's shawls for eight years. He is 39 years old and married with three children. Abdugafur began selling to acquaintances and friends and, after a while, he realized that he had a lot of clients. So, he decided to rent a shop and establish himself in the market. He is a very enterprising man with a great desire to get ahead. His business has been able to show the fruits of his labor and he hopes to grow as a businessman. Abdugafur needs a loan of $1500 US, which he plans to invest in inventory in order to offer better service and variety to his clients. You can be an important part of the growth of this business. Today is your opportunity to help, have no doubt! More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, and Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To increasing working capital for development of the business

loans.name: Julia Njeri

texts.en:
Julia is 30 years old and the mother of two sons. Her husband, Francis, is a pastor in one of the local churches. They live in Zambezi on the outskirts of Nairobi town. She operates her tailoring business from within and most of her customers are fellow villagers and the people who attend church together.

Julia opened this business in the year 2008 and, since then, she has been able to establish a network of customers. This has enabled her to have a steady income for her family. She has not borrowed elsewhere and this is her first loan with KADET. She was introduced to KADET by her friends who formed a group then joined KADET.

Julia plans to invest in her business by buying a sewing machine which will cost 26,000 Kenyan shillings (Kshs) and some material for 4,000 Kshs, so that she can meet her customer's needs and also increase her family's income.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine and some material

loans.name: Sam-At

texts.en:
Mr. Sam-at, 38, has been a silk weaver since he was 25 years old. Sam-at sells his finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. His wife has been selling groceries for one year. She buys grocery items from Phnom Penh market for resale in her village.

Sam-at is asking for his first loan in the amount of $500 US to provide capital for his wife to purchase additional grocery items for resale. 

Sam-at and his wife, Mrs. Sony Siem, 36, have been married since 1990 and have three children: one son and two daughters. All of the children are in school. They live in the Muk Kampoul district of Koh Dach, a famous island located 30 kilometers along the Mekong River, roughly 15 kilometers northeast of Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To provide capital for his wife to purchase grocery items for resale

loans.name: Rima

texts.en: Rima is a 36-year-old divorced woman living with her parents. After getting 10 years of experience, she decided to open a beauty salon in her town in 2007. She offers hairdressing and beauty services to her clients. Her business has developed well over the past two years. Today, she is asking for a loan of $1,200 to buy merchandise for her shop such as makeup, hair colors, cosmetics products and other items to continue to serve her clientele.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 33 years old.  He has been using his bicycle to transport people and light goods from one place to another (locally known as boda-boda business) in Naivasha town since 2004.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan after paying his first loan well.  He plans to purchase 3 more bicycles and employ people to manage for him in the same industry.

He plans to venture into real estate in future, by buying pieces of land around town and build houses for rental.

loans.use: To buy 3 new bicycles

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 42 years old man who lives in Gaza, Palestine. He is married with seven young children. He owns a barn in which he has raised different kinds of cattle since 1990. He needs a loan of $2000 to do some maintenance works in the barn and to buy more cattle. Ahmad  has a successful business and would appreciate some help to continue his good work.

loans.use: to buy more cattle and maintain their barn

loans.name: Kevin

texts.en:
Kevin is 23 years old.  He has been operating in the boda-boda business (transporting people and light goods in town using a bicycle) in Naivasha town since 2008.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan after paying his first loan well.  He plans to purchase 2 more bicycles and employ people to operate them for him in the same industry.  He will buy one manual bicycle and one which has an engine.

His immediate future plan is to buy a motorcycle to operate in transport.  The upgrade from the bicycle will increase his source of income.

loans.use: To buy 2 more new bicycles

loans.name: Morning Star Group

texts.en:
Nowah T. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called Morning Star. She is 42 years old and is married with 5 children aged 2 -24 years old and their educational levels are 2nd -11th grade. She also cares for a niece and a nephew. Nowah did not continue her own education past the 7th grade due to early marriage, that she had to start producing children for her husband. She and her family live and work in the Cotton Tree community in Harbel Margibi county Liberia.

Her business is the sales of a local Liberian dish made from rice dust called Kalama. She buys rice to soak and grind to be cooked like cream of wheat. After she prepares her Kalama, she then puts it in a cooler to be sold per cup to residents of community in Harbel.
 
She has been running this business for 3 years and hopes to get into the sales of plastic materials in the near future. Nowah started selling with 300.00 Liberian Dollars that was given to her by her husband as working capital. She keeps her food and environment very clean in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Nowah needs this loan to purchase more rice and sugar to produce more Kalama to serve her customers. She dreams of her giving her children good education.

In the photo that accompanies this profile,Nowah is the lady standing in the right of the photo.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more rice and sugar to produce more Kalama to serve her customers.

loans.name: Yakubdjon's Group

texts.en:
B. Yakubdjon is 50 years old. Together with his wife they have raised two children. Yakubdjon is an experienced bread baker. He has been doing this business for more than 30 years. Yakubdjon is baking the national bread “lepeshka” at home. His children and wife (pictured) help him with his business. Having many customers Yakubdjon is selling the majority of his products just from his place. However, he is also running the trading place in the central local market for selling the”lepeshka”. Now Yakubdjon requests $3000 USD. He is planning to purchase the flour at wholesale for his business. Yakubdjon is grateful for all supporting him and promises to manage the loan with accuracy.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing the flour as a wholesale for baking the national bread “lepeshka”.

loans.name: Balakhan

texts.en: Balakhan A. is 46 years old and sells construction materials in the small village of Agsu city. He is married and has three children. Balakhan has nine years of experience in this field. He rents a store in the crowded square and  that’s why his shop is always full of customers. Balakhan applied for a loan amounting to 1600 AZN to purchase more merchandise to increase his income.

loans.use: purchase more  items to sell

loans.name: United Friend Progressive Organization Group

texts.en:
For 26 years, Martin G. has had a used shoes business on Randall Street in Monrovia. He is 52 years old, married, and has six children who range in age from 4 to 21. In addition to his children, Martin also supports his sibling. 

Martin’s business is in a convenient location which keeps his customers returning. He started his business with 100 Liberian dollars (LRD) and is now operating with 25,000 LRD. Martin plans to use his 12,000 LRD portion of this 66,000 LRD group loan to leave the sidewalk and move into a store. His goal is to be productive in life and to grow his business. 

Martin is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "United Friend Progressive Organization". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Martin is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To move his business from the sidewalk into a store

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar has been working as a farmer for the past 12 years. He is a married man, 51 years old, and has three children. He owns land and cultivates it with a variety of fruits and vegetables according to the season. His children help in the household and they cooperate as a family to better their living conditions. 

Today, Omar is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy seeds and fertilizers for the summer cultivation.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Farogat

texts.en:
I. Farogat sells toys for children. She is 58 years old, married and has five children. She rents a place to sell her goods which is located in one of the local markets. Farogat has been running this business for 16 years. With only a couple of competitors in the market, she is doing well with her business. Today she is requesting a loan of $1200 US to purchase new toys and increase her range of goods. Farogat thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to be accurate with her loan repayments. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.use: To purchase toys

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more fish

loans.name: Buthayna

texts.en: Buthayna is a 40-year-old woman who lives in Gaza, Palestine. She is married with six children. Since 2009 she has owned a store that sells different kinds of goods, like clothes, stationary, and toys. She needs a loan of $3,000 to be able to increase the stock in her store. This loan will help her maintain good work and the ability to support her children. She is a very motivated, thoughtful woman who seeks help to continue her successful small business.

loans.use: To increase stock and profit

loans.name: Aiyom

texts.en:
K. Aiyom, age 41, sells an assortment of different kinds of good quality flour. Because he buys the flour wholesale, his price is cheaper than the price of his competitors. Thus, he has many customers who purchase flour straight from his house. He also has a successful business selling flour at the local market in the Isfara region. Today he has great demand for his goods and that is why he wants to take out an individual loan. Aiyom has requested a loan of 5000 somoni to add to his working capital and allow him to purchase more inventory. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices, and push every once in a while, to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business. loans.use: To purchase flour

loans.name: Djamshedkhon

texts.en:
Djamshedkhon dedicates his time to driving a taxi and a microbus. He is a 30-year-old man, married with two children. He has about five years of experience in the public transportation field. The competition is rather high in this business, since there are so many people who need it. Djamshedkhon currently relies on a microbus for his public transport business, which he drives personally. His current request is so that he can maintain his vehicle, since this is the tool of his trade. So now Djamshedkhon is counting on your help and requesting a loan of 4500 somoni. With the loan, he’ll purchase spare parts for his microbus. With your support, Djamshedkhon will continue to progress. More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. loans.use: To purchase spare parts in order to repair his microbus

loans.name: Maxym

texts.en:
Maxym is married and does not yet have any children. He owns a small business where he sells various home products.
Maxym started this business about one year ago. He graduated from college but, because of the high unemployment rate, he could not find a decent job. Therefore he decided to become self-employed and he started his own business.
Maxym is asking for a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase more stock. His desire is to develop his business as it is the only source of income for his young family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock

loans.name: Fatmata Sankoh Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Fatmata S. group, named after the group’s leader. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city, northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,400,000 each to expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Fatmata S.. Fatmata is 46 and was born in Makeni. She is married with 6 children. Her husband is a businessman. 4 of her children are adults and 2 are attending secondary school.  For 10 years now, Fatmata has been selling items such as cigarettes, batteries, lollipops, powdered milk, drinks and bathing soap. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying more stock wholesale to add to her current inventory. 

(In the left of the photo is loan officer, Solomon Beah, handing over the loan to the group's leader)

loans.use: To buy stock wholesale for resale

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth O. is 32 years old, married and has 3 children. She owns a salon/boutique in Kisumu, Kenya. She has received a KES 60,000 loan from SMEP to buy additional clothing stock. Ruth's customers come from all walks of life and are both locals and foreigners that visit the area. She claims that the challenges she faces are high competition and high rent as her business is located in the city center. 

Ruth has been in the same business for 15 years and she describes herself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of women's clothing

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
S. Rano is 45 years old. She is married and is the mother of 4 children. For many years her husband has worked in Russia. Supporting her family on her own was very difficult. 

To improve her living conditions, Rano decided to start her own business processing dried clingstone apricots and selling them at the local market. The business has gone very well and now Rano needs a loan in order to meet the demand of her customers. She is requesting a loan of $1000 USD to purchase more clingstone apricots. Rano feels this is the only way to earn enough to ensure that her children can stay in school and have a bright future.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: To buy clingstone apricots for processing and selling

loans.name: Benson

texts.en: Benson N. is a 26 year old owner of a motorcycle transport business in Thika, Kenya. He has received a loan of KES 20,000 to purchase a new motorcycle. Benson desires to be a leader in the local passenger ferrying industry. He is married with a 6 month old child. His challenges are cut-throat competition from other motorcycle taxi operators in the area. He describes himself as innovative and hardworking.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Benkan (5 mariées et 1veuve) ont en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et vivent  toutes dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier Banankabougou de la ville de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république.
Ces femmes se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de fruits et légumes, de condiments, de céréales, du savon, des tubercules etc et de la transformation.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les six prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Benkan sont à leur septième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 1 tonne de céréales, des colis de plusieurs variétés de condiments et quelques chargements d’oranges.
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes d’une façon ambulante et au marché, généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui servira à essentiellement étoffer leur fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The six women of the group Benkan (five married and one widowed) average 35 years of age and four children each. They live in traditional families in the Banankabougou district of the city of Fana, prefecture of Dioila, in the 2nd administrative region of the republic. These women know one another by community ties. They do commerce in a variety of goods, such as fruits and vegetables, condiments, grains, soap, tubers, etc. And they process goods. After having correctly repaid the six preceding loans, the women of the group are on their seventh solidarity loan, which will be used to buy a tonne of grain, some packages of several types of condiments, and a few loads of oranges. The goods are essentially acquired locally from producers and wholesale merchants. And sales are made door-to-door and at the market, generally in cash transactions with customers composed of women and men. The group members each envision making an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to build up their capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying food items

loans.name: Ulugbek

texts.en:
K. Ulugbek is a 33-year-old married man with 4 children and parents under his care. Ulugbek is a hard-working man who, while continuing to work another job, started his own business as a source of additional income and savings in case of unemployment. He knew many people who purchased sheep and this motivated him to start his own business 5 years ago. Over time, he has increased his sheep sales and he is proud to say that the business has been running well. Now Ulugbek needs additional capital to expand and is requesting a loan in the amount of $2200 USD to purchase additional sheep to sell. More specifically, he will reinvest the loan proceeds and grow the business, as he has been doing. Ulugbek and his family thank you very much for the support that you offer them in helping to expand his business and give their children a better quality of life.

loans.use: Purchasing of the sheep to expand the business.

loans.name: Sattorkul

texts.en:
O. Sattorkul is a 52-year-old farmer, who lives with his wife and four children in the northern part of Tajikistan, in the Shahristan region. Sattorkul has four cows and has eight years of experience in raising cattle and selling dairy products to local traders. Milk products are in great demand in his village and Sattorkul’s orders for them are very high. But the milk his cows give is not enough for the traders so he decided to apply for 7000 Somoni to purchase an additional cow and fodder. Sattorkul is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to improve his living with this loan.
