IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing a cow for his dairy business

loans.name: Anas

texts.en: Anas is a 20-year-old young man who lives in Gaza, Palestine.  Anas is a motivated university student who is working in his gift shop to be able to continue his studies. He needs a loan of $3,000 to increase the stock in his shop.  He started his business in 2008, and he is hoping he will have a secure income at least until he graduates from the university.

loans.use: To increase the stock in his shop

loans.name: Anthonia

texts.en: Anthonia is a good LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Anthonia is 40 years old and married with seven children. Her children are excelling in their jobs and education. She sells drinks at wholesale and retail prices to her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 40,000 to purchase more drinks to sell to improve her business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Tarana

texts.en:
Tarana M. is 57 years old and married, and she is the loving mother of one son. Tarana’s husband is currently unemployed, so her business is the main source of income for her family.

Tarana has a grocery store where she sells sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks, detergents and other products. She has been in this business for ten years. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Tarana is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her store to buy groceries again. 

Tarana wants to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 1600 AZN to increase the inventory she has for sale.

loans.use: purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Hector

texts.es:
Héctor O. tiene 47 años de edad oriundo de la ciudad de Roque González está casado hace 23 años con Sra. Petrona Fleitas de 50 años de edad, tienen 5 hijos, 2 en edad escolar y 3 que ya son mayor de edad y gracias a sus padres  son todos profesionales.
      Hace 20 años empezó con una pequeña despensa en su domicilio, que gracias a la ayuda de su esposa pudo aprovechar para continuar con su carrera de docencia y así poder ejercer la docencia y a la ves seguir contando con su negocio que ayuda con los  ingresos. 
        Solicitó el préstamo para la compra de mercaderías como ser bebidas y artículos de primera necesidad como:  Harina, yerba, fideos y arroz en cantidad.
texts.en:
Héctor O., 47, is a native of the city of Roque González. He has been married for 23 years to Sra. Petrona Fleitas, 50, and they have 5 children, 2 still of school age. Thanks to their parents, their 3 grown children are all professionals. Twenty years ago he started a small mini-mart in his home, and thanks to the help of his wife he was also able to continue his teaching career, thus able to both teach and continue his business to help with the family income. He has requested this loan to buy stock such as soft drinks and basic necessities such as flour, yerba, noodles, and rice in bulk.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grocery stock

loans.name: True Faith Group

texts.en:
Weedor F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called True Faith. She is 49 years old and is married with five children aged 14 - 32 years old. Their educational levels are 5th grade - 12th grade. She also cares for two nephews and a niece. She is illiterate due to her father’s decision that only his male children he would be educated. Weedor and her family live in Dolo’s town and work in the Harbel market, Harbel, Margibi County in Liberia.

Her business is the sale of garden eggs (African eggplant) and peppers. She buys her products at wholesale and sells at retail on a table in the Harbel market.  She has been running this business for more than three years and hopes to grow her business to a bigger level in the near future. 

She talks to her customers in a friendly manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Weedor will use this loan to purchase more garden eggs and peppers for resale to improve business. She dreams of providing her children with an education so that they can have a better future.  
In the photo that accompanies this profile, Weedor is the lady standing on the right. 

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more garden eggs and peppers for resale.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen sells foodstuffs and fruit at retail prices to her customers. She is 40 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a commercial motorcyclist and he supports the home. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She needs a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and fruit to sell. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and fruits to sell.

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Titus N. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called In God We Trust. He is 32 years old and is married with three children aged 6-14 years old.  Their educational levels are 2nd to 4th grades. He also cares for two siblings.  Titus and his family live in the Old Road community, and he works in Old Road Joe Bar Market in Monrovia, Liberia.  He was never able to go to school himself due to a lack of financial support from his parents.

Titus’ business is the sale of used clothes. He buys his goods from a wholesaler and sells them in the market. He has been running this business for two years and hopes to own a big store in the near future.  Titus started by purchasing clothes individually but now buys in bulk to increase his profits.

He presents his clothes in a nice manner in order to encourage people to buy from him.  Titus needs this loan to purchase additional used clothes. He dreams of improving his living standard.

In the photo accompanying this profile, Titus is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional used clothes.

loans.name: Asif

texts.en:
Asif M. is 26 years old and a very enthusiastic young man who has been selling different kinds of domestic goods since 2005. Asif is single but responsible for supporting his parents who are unemployed. His shop is the only source of income in Asif's family but the income that his shop brings him is not enough to build his own family. 

Asif believes one day he will have a big family with many children. For this purpose Asif applied for a loan in the amount of 1600 AZN, as he believes this loan will help him to increase his profit. Let’s do our best to help this hard-working man.

loans.use: purchase more merchandise to increase profit

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith is a single parent with two children. She is 32 years old. Her children are excelling in school and this makes her happy. She sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization). LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 30,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Milkah

texts.en:
Milkah is 29 years old and married to Daniel Karimi. They are parents to one child, who is in nursery school. Her husband is involved in mobile-phone repairs. They stay in Kikuyu, where Milkah has also put up her retail shop business. This rural/urban kind of a town is very industrious and ideal for business. She has been in this kind of business for the last two years. Her customers are mainly small-scale retailers.

Milkah has not borrowed from other sources and this is her first loan with KADET, a Kiva partner. Together with some of her friends, she formed a group and joined. Milkah plans to add plasticware to her shop, as well as add more stock to the shop of other items like tea leaves, sweets, food spices and many more.

She hopes to grow her business to a wholesale trade so that she can be supplying to others within the town.

loans.use: Milkah plans to buy plasticware items and put them up outside her shop, and also add more stock to her shop

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson is 38 years old. He is married to Miriam Auma and they have three school-going children. He has been in the motorcycle transport business for the last two years, operating in Naivasha town.

He was introduced to KADET, a Kiva partner, by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy a new motorcycle and will employ someone else to operate it for him. This will increase his income.

His future dream is to buy a minibus, which he will also use in the transport business.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Shadi

texts.en: Shadi is a very ambitious farmer who started raising chickens in 2004. He is a 27-year-old single man who wants to prosper with his project to make enough money to get married and have a big family. He lives in Beit lahia in Gaza, where they compete in raising cattle, chicken and farming. So he wants $3,000 to improve his work by buying advanced equipment for chicken raising and by purchasing air conditioning that will help increase his chickens' health and eventually increase his sales. Shadi appreciates your help and promises to make use of it in the best way to prosper in his work.

loans.use: To buy advanced equipment

loans.name: Ebson

texts.en:
Ebson K. I. currently owns a small trolley from which he sells sausages in the town of Thika, Kenya. He sells to local people of all types and ages. Currently he is self-employed, but his goals with the loan from SMEP are to purchase additional trolleys to rent out to other people to generate additional income. 

Ebson, his wife, and 2 kids have no other source of income in the household, and he also states that an additional challenge is harassment from the local city council due to his business being located in an open air market. Eventually, Ebson would like to start a restaurant business. He describes himself as kind, patient, humble, and says he loves people.

loans.use: to purchase additional food carts to rent out to other people

loans.name: United Group

texts.en:
Tumu S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Group. She is 43 years old and single. She has five children, who are 1, 5, 19, 21 and 25 years old.

For 10 years, Tumu has been selling dry goods, such as bananas, oranges and peanuts, on Newport Street. She started her business with 1,000 Liberian dollars and now is operating with 6,000 Liberian dollars. She has a good relationship with her customers, which keeps people returning.  

Tumu plans to use her 12,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 40,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bananas, oranges and peanuts. Her goal is to grow her business to the shop level and to be in good health.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Tumu is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas, oranges and peanuts

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen has a farm where she plants cassava to sell to resellers. She also sells fruit and cassava dough.  She is a hard working woman and she hopes to lift her family and business above poverty. She is 35 years-old and married with eight children. Her children are still young and dependent on her. She is a Kiva partner Lift Above Poverty Organisation (LAPO) client. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cassava stems to plant and sell. She says a big thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase cassava stems.

loans.name: Margaret Wambui

texts.en:
Margaret is 39 years-old and unmarried. She has two children. aged 10 years and 19 years, respectively. She lives in Muthiga where she also has her retail shop. She has been selling different items in her shop for the last four years and now has stable and reliable customers.

She was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend and this will be her first time to seek a loan. She has no previous credit history and she plans to use the loan amount to restock her retail shop with items such as detergent, flour, tea leaves, tissue paper, etc.

Margaret intends to enlarge her shop by becoming a wholesaler supplying other retailers within the surrounding areas of Muthiga. This will enable her to eventually improve her living standard and the lives of her children.

loans.use: To increase her store stock.

loans.name: Monday

texts.en:
Monday F. sells various items in a retail shop and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and beans to sell.  Monday is 35 years-old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has two children and both go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a car that will be used as a taxi.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.  BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase rice and beans.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is old man who is 57 years old. He is married and has three children, ages 8, 14, and 18. Charles and his family live in the Kicukiro District, Kigali Province in the village Kanombe near the international airport in Rwanda. This is also the place where his business is location. 

Charles, alone, works to provide for the basic needs of his family by selling various styles of clothes. Charles chose this business because it is profitable and easy. His business is very organized. Charles employs two people as helpers in his business so that his business runs smoothly.

Charles is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by purchasing an various additional clothes. His business is known in his region. He needs to expand his product line to satisfy his customers by offering them the good quality clothes in various styles. The profits that Charles expects to obtain will help him to save money for his family and pay the school fees for his children.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: Agnes Njeri

texts.en:
Agnes is married to Stanley and they have three sons. Agnes is a green grocer, mainly selling fruit within an area called Ruaka on the outskirts of Nairobi. She has been in this business for a while. Her husband is also a businessman within the same town. 

Agnes was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend and she has no previous credit history. This is her first loan and she is optimistic that it will help her boost her business especially after she increases her stock of fruits for sale.

Agnes desires to expand her business by opening a general shop so that she can accommodate other products to cater for most of the needs of her clients.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit.

loans.name: Elbrus

texts.en:
Elbrus A. is 28 years old and is an entrepreneur who sells different kinds of engine oil for cars. He started his business eight years ago when he purchased a car and every time when he needed to change engine oil, he had to go many kilometers away from his home village.  Elbrus decided to open the store in the village where he lives which has become very popular among local people. 

Elbrus has two children and he believes one day they will continue his business.  For this purpose he applied for a loan in the amount of 1600 AZN.

loans.use: purchase and diversify his stock of engine oil for cars

loans.name: Siliman

texts.en:
Siliman D. sells clothes in the market and is requesting a loan to buy more clothes to sell.  Siliman is 45 years-old and a widow.  She has two children and both go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a supermarket.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.  BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing is married with six children and her husband moulds blocks to support the home. She sells groceries, bags clothes, bags and foodstuffs. With these combined businesses she hopes to meet the basic needs and necessities of her family.

She hopes to expand her business and improve her family’s standard of living by making more profits from her business. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries, food, clothes, shoes, and bags to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, food, clothes, shoes, and bags to sell.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama was born in 1957. She is married and has four children between the ages of 8 and 23. Salama and her family live in Gasabo District, Kigali Province, in the capital of Rwanda, in the village called Gatsata. Her business is also located there. 

Salama owns a small shop where she sells spare parts. She has been an entrepreneur since 2005. Salama has decided to be a businesswoman because, before, when she was a farmer, she could not meet the needs of her family. So far so good, because she is able to sort out her family problems. Her business opens every day at 7:00 in the morning and is open until 9:00 in the evening every day except Saturday.

Salama is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand her business because, right now, Salama cannot satisfy the demands of her clients. Salama’s shop is situated in a good place because there is a bus station that is not far from her shop. Salama believes that she can earn more profits by selling more spare parts. With these profits, Salama will be able to save money for her children so she can pay their school fees.

loans.use: Purchasing more spare parts

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris sells hair and beauty accessories like shampoo, hair extensions and cosmetics at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because it is highly profitable and she hopes to grow her business. She is 27 years-old and unmarried without children. She has a good relationship with Kiva partner LAPO. Doris is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more hair and beauty accessories to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase hair and beauty accessories to sell.

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en: Abdallah is a 43-year-old married man with 4 children. He has been working in a cafeteria for the past 30 years. In 2008, after this long experience, he opened his own cafeteria. He has been able during this period to have a growing number of customers. Today, Abdallah is requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 to make some modifications and renovations to his cafeteria to attract more customers.

loans.use: make some modifications and renovations to his cafeteria

loans.name: Sana'

texts.en:
"My son loves birds. It started as a hobby and now he has a small bird shop. I want to help him fulfill his dream," Sana' says.

Sana' a mother of 10 children, all of whom are younger than 21 years old. Her son started catching birds, breeding, and selling them. Then he used his small capital to buy larger numbers of all types of birds. By the time he became well-known, he started a wholesale birds distribution business.

This small business is now an additional source of income for the family. The father is an employee of Karitas Hospital in Beth Lehem, but despite his fine salary, providing for the needs of a 12-member family is not easy nowadays.

loans.use: Purchase and breed birds

loans.name: Mujeres En Desarrollo Group

texts.es:
En la Ciudad de Carapeguá  en la Compañía Potrero distante a 5 km de la oficina de Carapeguá uñas señoras de escasos recursos se enteraron del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y decidieron reunirse para recibir una información sobre el mencionado programa.
 
Estas Señoras son activas muy trabajadoras y la mayoría se dedica a la actividad de artesanía (tejido de hamacas, sobrecamas). Ellas buscando un poco más de apoyo para fomentar a través del crédito sus ingresos familiares y mejorar su calidad de viD..

La señora Jorgelina es una de las integrantes del comité y también se dedica a tejido de hamacas y sobrecamas y la venden en varios negocios de varias ciudades como San Lorenzo, Capiata, Asunción. 
  
Necesitan de esta operación crediticia para invertir en sus respectivos trabajos y así poder lograr un crecimiento sostenible que les haga crecer como grupo y en forma individua.
texts.en:
In the city of Carapeguá, in the locality of Compañía Potrero, 5 kilometers from the Carapeguá office, some low-income women heard about the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras ("Committee of Entrepreneurial Women") and decided to meet for an informational session about this program. These women are active and very hard-working, and most of them work making handicrafts (weaving hammocks and bedspreads). Through this loan, they are seeking a little more support to increase their families' incomes and improve their quality of life. Jorgelina is one of the committee members, who also works weaving hammocks and bedspreads. Her creations are sold in various businesses in a range of cities, such as San Lorenzo, Capiata and Asunción. The group needs this loan to invest in their respective lines of business, and thus achieve sustainable growth which will allow them to make progress as individuals and as a group.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing thread and cloth strips for weaving

loans.name: Awney

texts.en: Awney owns a supermarket in a good area in Gaza and is hoping to increase his sales through a $3000 loan.  He wants to improve the interior of his store as well as buy new products and increase his stock.  He is 49 years-old and has four children that are studying in school with one in college. He is hoping to have enough money to send all his children to college.

loans.use: To enhance his store with new products and a better interior.

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 35 years old and single. Francoise takes care of five dependents between the ages of 5 and 14. These dependents are relatives. This big family lives in Nyarugenge District in the Kigali Province in the village called Gitega where her business is located. Francoise has a business selling cow meat. She has 15 years of experience in this business. Her business is open every day from 6:00 in the morning to 6:00 in the evening. 

Francoise is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by purchasing more meat to sell. In fact, Francoise does not have enough money to invest, so she is requesting a loan. The profits Francoise expects to earn will help her to reinvest in her business. This will allow her to sort out her family problems.

loans.use: To buy more cow meat to sell

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en: Bassam, 26 years old, single and living with his two parents, opened his optic shop in his town in 2007 after graduating from university in this major. This business satisfies the high market demand for optical services in the entire region. Today, Bassam is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy additional sunglasses, medical eyeglasses, lenses etc. to meet his client's requirements.

loans.use: To buy additional sunglasses, medical eyeglasses, lenses

loans.name: Milka

texts.en: Milka J. is a 41-year-old fish monger from Kisumu, Kenya whose business is located in the central business district of the town. She faces competition from other fish peddlers and also is subject to the rising prices of fresh fish. Milka, widowed with four children, dreams of being able to educate all of her children to the university level. Within five years, she hopes to expand her business sufficiently to be able to supply fish to markets outside of the town. She describes herself as hardworking, tolerant, and committed.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for her business

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
El Sr Pedro M. vive en la ciudad de San Roque Gonzalez, a unos 15 Km de Carapeguá; es un señor muy trabajador,  desde muy joven se dedicó a  ayudar a sus padres  ya que los mismos no podían  sustentar los gastos de la casa. 
Ya adulto el Sr. Pedro decidió comenzar un negocio cual es la venta de ropas y calzados a crédito, al tener más pedidos de mercaderías se vio con la necesidad de recurrir a nuestra institución para solicitar préstamo de manera a que pueda aumentar su capital. 
Solicitó el préstamo para la compra de sábanas, hamacas, calzados ya que ha recibido muchos pedidos de estas mercaderías se parte de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Pedro M. lives in the city of San Roque Gonzalez, 15 km from Carapegúa. He is a hard-worker and has worked since very young to support his parents who could not afford the household costs. As an adult, Pedro decided to begin a business in the sales of clothing and shoes on credit. Upon receiving a greater number of orders than merchandise, he saw the need to come to our institution to request a loan to increase his working capital.

He has requested this loan to purchase curtains, hammocks and shoes, since he has received many orders for this merchandise from his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bed covers, curtains, hammocks and shoes

loans.name: Akimana

texts.en:
H. is 34 years old and married. She cares for three children, ages 1, 11 and 13. H. and her family live in the Kicukiro District, in the capital of Rwanda.

H. works as businesswoman, as does her husband. H. owns a small shop where she sells different kinds of shoes in the Kigali. Her husband has a small restaurant. They both work to support their family. H.'s business is actually very organized and well-known. It requires two employees to run her her business. H. has two years of experience. The hours of her shop are from 6:00 AM to 9:00 PM every day except on the weekend.

H. is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by purchasing more and different styles of shoes, especially shoes for children. With the profits she plans to earn, H. will be able to get all of the basic needs of her family, save money for her family, especially for her children, build her own house, and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: Purchasing more shoes for sale

loans.name: Tareza

texts.en:
Tareza D. sells food in a hotel and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer and sodas to sell.  Tareza is 40 years-old and a widow.   She has six children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open another place to sell food.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.  BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To buy beer and sodas.

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is 28 years old and single. Jean de Dieu lives with his parents in the Gasabo District in the capital of Rwanda where his business is located. He sells different kinds of products and using a sewing machine. All of these businesses help him to obtain more profits. Some of various products are sugar, sorghum flour, and so on. The sewing machine is used while he is waiting for the customers. Jean de Dieu works so hard for his progress that he earns more profits than one of his family members who is the executive secretary the the center government. They both work for their progress and their families.

Jean de Dieu is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his small shop so that he can obtain more profits. Jean de Dieu is serious man in his activities. His business hours are from 7:00 in the morning to 7:00 in the evening every day except Sunday. With the profits Jean de Dieu expects to earn, he will reinvest in his business.

loans.use: Purchasing more products for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero is 40 years-old and married with four children. Her husband is a businessman. Her children are still dependent on her and they attend school. She owns a beer parlour where she sells drinks, groceries and rechargeable phone cards at retail prices. She hopes to expand her business to attract more customers. She looks forward to having a classic restaurant in the future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drinks, groceries and rechargeable phone cards to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, groceries and rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Frederic

texts.en:
Frederic is 30 years old and single. Frederic lives with his parents, so he has to contribute to the life of his parents and brothers. Frederic and his parents live in the Gasabo District, Kigali Province,in the capital of Rwanda where his business is located. Frederic owns a small shop where she sells various products, such as cosmetics, lock machines, and nuts.

Frederic is a hard-working man. He has had his business since 2003 and his business is known to be well-organized. Frederic employs one person so that his business runs well. 

Frederic is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by purchasing more products. The hours of his business are from 8:00 in the morning to 8:00 in the evening every day except Sunday. Frederic has a goal -- he needs to become a wholesaler, which will help him to obtain more profits. With the profits that Frederic expects to earn, he will reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: San Juan Group

texts.es:
En la localidad de Quiindy en el Barrio San Lorenzo distante a 23km de la oficina de Carapeguá unas señoras de escasos recursos se enteraron del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y decidieron reunirse para recibir una información sobre el mencionado programa. 

Estas Señoras son activas la y todas de dedican a una actividad independiente así como al comercio de productos de la canasta familiar, confección de ropas, artesanía. 
Ellas buscando un poco más de apoyo para fomentar a través del crédito sus ingresos familiares y mejorar su calidad de vida.
En caso de la Sra, Juana Q. quien se dedica a la negocio de ventas de todo tipo de productos de la canasta basica familiar como fideos, panificados, leche, azucar, arroz y otros. El crédito que ella solicitó lo invertirá para la compra de estos productos. 
El negocio es muy visitado por todos sus vecinos y  la venta de sus productos es bastante buena, y esto ayuda a que la alimentación de su familia se sustente con los ingresos del negocio.
Necesitan de esta operación crediticia para invertir en sus respectivos trabajos y así poder lograr un crecimiento sostenible que les haga crecer como grupo y en forma individual
texts.en:
In the Quiindy section of the neighborhood of Barrio San Lorenzo, 23 km from Carapegúa, some women of scarce resources found out about the Committee of Businesswomen program and decided to meet to receive information about the above-mentioned program.

These women are active, and they all work in independent businesses including the sale of traditional basket products, garment production, artisan work.

They are looking for a little more support through credit to boost their family incomes and improve their quality of life.

In the case of Juana Q., she works in the sale of various kinds of products from traditional baskets to noodles, bread, milk, sugar, rice and others. The loan that she requests will be invested in these products.

Her business is frequented by all the neighbors and the sale of her products is quite good. This helps her to feed her family and sustain them with the earnings from her business.

They need credit from this operation to invest in their respective work in order to achieve sustainable growth so that they can grow as a group and in their individual manners.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise such as meat, rice, noodles, clothes, vegetables etc.

loans.name: Sabine

texts.fr: Sabine D. est une femme de 49 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de MBORO depuis 10 et a eu 20 expériences avec le crédit. Avec son nouveau prêt elle compte développer un petit commerce de tissus; du tissus qu'elle achète en gros pour revendre au détail dans son quartier. Son objectif est de subvenir aux besoins familiaux et d'assurer en partie le ravitaillement alimentaire mensuellement.
texts.en:
Sabine D. is a 49-year-old woman who is married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de MBORO for ten years and has had twenty loan experiences. With her new loan, she intends to develop her small fabrics business. She buys fabrics wholesale to sell retail in her area. Her goal is to provide for the family and to make sure in part that food is resupplied each month.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her investment capacity

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 29 years old and married with a child who is four years old. Her husband is a civil servant and he supports the home. Janet sells cosmetics like lipsticks, beauty powder and bathing soap. She has been in this business for eight years. She hopes to see her business grow bigger in the near future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna N. is currently in the business of selling greens and tomatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more greens and fruits to sell.  Anna is 22 years old and is married to a fisherman. She has two children who do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more greens and fruits to sell

loans.name: Blanca Lila

texts.es:
La Sra. Blanca esta casada con el Sr. Pablo Rodriguez desde ase ya 24 años con quien tiene 4 hijos.
Blanca desde siempre se dedico a la cría de chachos. En la actualidad posee un criadero de cerdos que lo comercializa en las carnicerías de la zona, también gracias a los créditos que la Fundación le ha otorgado pudo comprar para sus vacas, ahora tiene 20 vacas.
La señora Blanca como siempre hizo, todos los créditos que retira de la Fundación los destina a la compra de animales y así poder satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes y obtener una mayor ganancia.
texts.en:
Blanca is married to Pablo Rodriguez, since 24 years ago, with whom she has 4 children. Blanca has always worked raising pigs. Currently, she has a farm for pigs that she sells in the butchers in the neighborhood. Also, thanks to the loans that the Foundation has granted to her, she was able to purchase cows. Now, she has 20 cows.

Blanca has used all her loans from the Foundation to purchase animals, and in this way she satisfies the demand of her customers and obtains better profits.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase animal vaccines and pigs

loans.name: Omar

texts.en: Omar, a 28-year-old married man with two young children, has been working as a farmer for the past 12 years. He learned this occupation from his father who also worked in the agriculture sector. He cultivates all types of vegetables and distributes the harvest to the market to be sold. Today, Omar is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy farming supplies such as seeds and fertilizers to increase his production.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies like seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Zahi

texts.en: Zahi is a 29-year-old single man who lives with his three brothers and sisters. After the death of his parents, he became the sole provider for his family. He has worked as a farmer for the past 15 years. Zahi is collaborating with an agriculturA. market to which he distributes his harvested vegetables. Today, Zahi is requesting to borrow $1,000 USD to buy seeds and fertilizers that he needs for the summer cultivation.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes P. is a 55-year-old married woman who lives in Prk. Bombills Brgy Old Sagay, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fleet of 6 motorized fishing boats. Mercedes’s husband Esidoro is 55 years old, and they have 4 children. Three of their children work to support themselves and only one child is currently going to school.

Mercedes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in fishing. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 32,000 from her business activities.

Mercedes is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 was used to fund the operations of her fishing business, and it had a positive impact on both her business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 11th loan, in the amount of PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to purchase another fishing boat to add to her fleet of 6. Mercedes is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase another fishing boat.

loans.name: Ma. Lyn

texts.en:
Ma. Lyn B. is a married woman who supports her family by selling Ready-to-Wear (RTW) clothes, vegetable vending and doing other networking sales activities. She lives in Brgy. Basak, Cuayan Negros Occidental with her husband and their 6 children.  Her children are 5 to 17 years old; one works and 5 are currently studying and also helping their parents.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000.

Ma. Lyn is now borrowing PHP 20,500 so that she can continue with her multiple business activities, the bulk of which is selling RTW clothes. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. A previous loan of PHP 20,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ma. Lyn aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase additional working capital.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica sells groceries such as milk, noodles, bread, biscuits, juice and sachet water. She started this business 2 years ago and she is recording progress daily. She is married with two children, a set of twins who are 3 years old. Monica is 33 years old and lives in Sapele, Delta State with her family. She supports her husband in meeting the family's needs. Her husband works with the local government. Monica needs a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She hopes to own a super market in the future. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 30-year-old married man who lives with his parents. Along with his brothers, he contributes to the family income. Ahmad has owned a barber shop in his town for the past 15 years. He caters to a wide range of customers from his village and the surrounding neighborhoods. Today, Ahmad wishes to improve the decor of his barber shop and buy new tools to satisfy the demands of his occupation. In order to do so, Ahmad is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD.

loans.use: To improve the decor of his barber shop and buy new tools

loans.name: Oliva

texts.en:
Oliva is 25 years old. She is an unmarried mother. She cares for two children, ages 2 and 3. Oliva lives in the Nyarugenge District, Kigali Province in the capital of Rwanda, where she has her business. Oliva has been an entrepreneur for many years. She employs two people in her business as helpers so that her business runs well. 

Oliva has 6 years of experience selling cow meat. This business is very interesting for her because is profitable, even when she has little money, all of which is used for her business.

Oliva would like to request a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by purchasing large quantities of meat. Thiswill allow her to continue to develop her business. 

The hours of her shop are from 7:00 in the morning to 6:00 in the evening every day, even during the weekend. It seems that Oliva is serious about her business. That is the reason that she will reach her goal of expanding her business and increasing her monthly profits.

loans.use: To buy cows for meat

loans.name: Virgen De La Candelaria Group

texts.es:
El comité Mujeres Virgen de la Candelaria del barrio Las Mercedes de Aregua localidad muy cercana a la ciudad de Luque, se formo con integrantes del comité Virgen de las Mercedes del mismo barrio, las cuales quisieron formar un nuevo comité mas cerca de sus casas,  actualmente el comité se encuentra en el primer ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya y esta conformado por 15 integrantes las cuales invierten en distintas actividades.
Todas se dedican a diferentes actividades así como señora Graciela T. tiene una despensa en el que  invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías al por mayor para el incremento de los productos su negocio. 

La señora Rossana S. se dedica a la venta de mercería e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías varias para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Ermelinda C. se dedica a la venta de comestible e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para la elaboración y venta de los mismos.

La señora Natalia S. se dedica a la venta de helados e invirtió el dinero en la compra de helados de varios gustos para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Cecilia S. es peluquera e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos tales como cremas, shampoo, cosméticos, para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Victorina P. se dedica a la venta de bebidas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías al por mayor para la venta de los mismos.

La señora María Teresa J. se dedica a la alfarería e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos tales como barros, arcilla y otros, para la elaboración de sus mercaderías.

La señora Norma V. se dedica a la veta de ropas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de remeras, bermudas, short, blusas entre otros para el incremento de sus ventas.

La señora Gloria R. se dedica a la elaboración y venta de dulces e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para la elaboración de los mismos.

La señora Hilda B. se dedica a la venta de helados e invirtió el dinero en la compra de helados de varios gustos para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Francisca T. se dedica a la venta de productos de limpieza e invirtió el dinero en la compra de químicos para la elaboración y venta de sus productos.

La señora Lorenza D. tiene una despensa e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías al por mayor para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Adriana D. se dedica a la venta de mercería e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías varias para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Nelida Velastiqui se dedica a la alfarería e invirtio el dinero en la compra de insumos tales como barros, arcilla y otros, para la elaboración de sus mercaderías.

La señora Viviana A. se dedica a la venta de comestible e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para la elaboración y venta de los mismos.

La señora Gloria V. se dedica a la alfarería e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos tales como barros, arcilla y otros, para la elaboración de sus mercaderías.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Virgen de la Candelaria Communal Bank is from the Las Mercedes de Aregua neighborhood, which is very close to the city of Luque. The group was formed by members from the Virgen de las Mercedes Communal Bank of the same neighborhood. They wanted to form a new communal bank closer to their homes. The communal bank is currently in their first cycle of the Women Entrepreneurs program at Fundación Paraguaya. The group is comprised of 15 members who engage in different activities. All of them work at different activities like Graciela T.. She has a grocery store, and she invested the money in buying merchandise wholesale in order to increase the products in her business. Rossana S. sells merchandise, and she invested the money in the purchase of various merchandise to increase her business. Ermelinda C. sells food. She invested the money in the purchase of supplies to make and sell food. Natalia S. sells ice cream, and she used the money to buy various flavors of ice cream to increase her business. Cecilia S. is a hairdresser. She used the money to buy supplies like creams, shampoo, and cosmetics to increase her business. Victorina P. sells drinks. She used the money to buy merchandise wholesale for resale. María Teresa J. sells pottery. She used the money to buy supplies like clay and other things to make her merchandise. Norma V. sells clothes. She used the money to buy t-shirts, Bermuda shorts, and blouses among other things to increase her sales. Gloria R. makes and sells sweets. She used the money to buy supplies to make sweets. Hilda B. sells ice cream. She used the money to buy various flavors of ice cream to increase her business. Francisca T. sells cleaning products. She used the money to buy chemicals to make and sell her products. Lorenza D. has a grocery store. She used the money to buy merchandise wholesale to increase her business. Adriana D. sells merchandise. She used the money to buy various merchandise to increase her business. Nelida Velastiqui sells pottery. She used the money to buy supplies like clay and other things to make her merchandise. Viviana A. sells food. She used the money to buy supplies to make the food. Gloria V. sells pottery. She used the money to buy supplies like clay and other things to make her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies and merchandise for their businesses

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled is 23 years old, married, and has one child. He has been working as a farmer since 2005. He cultivates all kind of vegetables according to the season.  He then uses a pick-up to take his harvested produce to the agricultural market with which he works. Khaled's work has improved during his time as a farmer and he plans to reinforce it. To do so, Khaled is asking to borrow $1,200 USD to buy additional farming supplies, seeds and fertilizers to improve and expand his cultivation of the land.

loans.use: To buy additional farming supplies, seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client with a good repayment record. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and else where in Africa. She sells groceries and foodstuffs like beans, rice, melon, tomatoes and milk. Christiana hopes to expand her business and is requesting a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell to increase her profits. Christiana is happily married with four children. Her children are still dependent on her and they attend school. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.fr: Catherine N. est âgée de 57 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants en charge. Elle est membre de du Banc Villageois MBORO depuis 10 ans et a 20 fois de suite été bénéficiaire de crédit. Elle mène deux activités à la fois: l'élevage de porcs et la vente de tissus. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de payer la scolarité de ses enfants et de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Catherine N. is 57 years old, she is married and the mother of 5 children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois MBORO for the past 10 years and has received 20 loans. She has two businesses right now: raising pigs and selling fabric. Her earnings enable her to pay for her children's school tuition and to take care of the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her capacity to invest in her business

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 35 years old and is married with four children who are 2, 3, 10 and 11 years old. She and her family live in the Nyarugenge district, one of the districts of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Jeanne is a proven entrepreneur and she has been selling a variety of drinks in her pub. The business hours are from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Jeanne is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of adding a large quantity of beers so that she can satisfy the demands of her customers. With this loan, Jeanne hopes to increase her sales as well her profits.

If this plan is successful, Jeanne will continue helping her husband to build a secure future for their family and, in addition, she will try to create some other sources of income in order to increase her profits and give more jobs to the people in her community.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of beers

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is married and has two unemployed children. He has worked as a farmer for the past 15 years. He only cultivates tomatoes and zucchini, and he is known in his town's agricultural market by these two products. Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow $1,200 USD to buy seeds and fertilizers for the next harvesting.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 50 years old and is married with two children. He and his family live in the Nyarugenge district of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Emmanuel lives by selling charcoal in this area and this is his eighth successful year in this business. The hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Emmanuel is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that he can expand his business through purchasing more sacks of charcoal. With this loan, Emmanuel hopes that the number of his customers will increase as well as his profits.

With these profits, Emmanuel will use one portion of his profits for reinvestment in his business and, in addition, he will keep taking care of his family through doing whatever is positive for them.

loans.use: To buy additional sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Speciose

texts.en:
Speciose is 53 years old and she is married with six children with ages 21, 23, 25, 27, 29 and 31 years. She lives in the Nyarugenge district, a region of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Speciose is a proven entrepreneur who has owned a restaurant for about two years. Her restaurant is open from 6 a.m. until the last client leaves.

Speciose, after realizing how the number of her customers is increasing, is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of increasing her restaurant in size and quantity. To achieve this, she will purchase more equipment and increase the quantity of food so that she can satisfy the demand of her customers.

If this plan is successful, Speciose hopes to earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to buy a refrigerator to use in cooling the drinks she sells to her customers, as they usually request it. With these profits, she will also continue to take care of her family and build a secure future for them.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment and food

loans.name: Sifa

texts.en:
Sifa is 31 years old and is married with one child. She and her little family live in the Gasabo district.

Sifa has been a self-employed businesswoman selling meat since 2003. The hours of her butcher shop are from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Sifa, during the time she was starting this business, could not get enough clients to the extent that she could not sell one cow per day. But now her number of customers has so much increased that she can't even satisfy them. Sifa needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that she can purchase one more cow for sale. She also wants to start selling the meat of sheep and hens.

With this additional business, Sifa hopefully will earn more profits. Those profits will allow her and her family to build a secure future for themselves and keep their business financially stable.

loans.use: To buy one more cow, sheep and hen

loans.name: Bonifride

texts.en:
Bonifride is 50 years old and is married with four children with ages 16, 23, 26 and 27. She and her family live in Nyarugenge district, one of the districts of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Here, Bonifride operates her business of selling a variety of goods in her shop, which is open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day except Saturday.

Bonifride is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through adding a large quantity of goods: mainly foodstuffs such as rice, corn flour, Irish potatoes, beans, etc.

With the use of this loan, Bonifride hopes to earn more profits which in turn will allow her to help her devoted husband to take care of their family through paying school fees for their children and providing more food for them. In addition, she will be able to save for further reinvestment in her business.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of goods for her store

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 25-year-old single man who lives with his mother and eight brothers and sisters. He works with them to generate a good income for the family and provide a better standard of living. He has been involved in the agriculture sector, working as a farmer, for the past 12 years. Today, Ali is asking for a loan of $1,200 USD to buy agriculturA. supplies.

loans.use: To buy agricultural supplies

loans.name: Claire

texts.en:
Claire is 29 years old and she is married. She lives in Nyarugenge district where has operated her business of selling clothes for about six years. The hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Claire is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing some other attractive clothing styles to sell as well as additional sizes and colors.

With this loan, Claire hopes to attract more customers to her shop and hopefully earn more profits in the process. This, in turn will allow her and her devoted husband to build a secure future for themselves as well as their future children.

loans.use: To buy other attractive clothing styles to sell as well as additional sizes and colors

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice loves sarongs and that is why she sells sarongs to make a living in Sapele, Delta state. She loves this business because she has the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 60,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She has children and she is happy that they are excelling in school. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her business. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Lucie

texts.en:
Lucie is 23 years old and she is still single. She lives in the Kicukiro district, one of the districts of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Lucie is in the business of selling a variety of goods in her shop. Those goods include cosmetics products, soft drinks and some food supplies. This is her third successful year in this business and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Although Lucie has been in this business for about three years, her profit is still too low to expand meaningfully and she believes that a small amount of additional capital would increase her sales as well as her profits. For that reason, Lucie is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase more goods to add to her shop.

With these additional goods, which seem to be highly in demand in her business area, Lucie hopes to earn more profits than previously. Through the use of this loan, she will build a secure future for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods for her shop

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
El comité Kuña Guapa del barrio San Juan de la ciudad de Luque, se formó gracias a la invitación que recibieron del comité Divino Niño Jesús del mismo barrio para la formación de un nuevo grupo. 

Actualmente el comité se encuentra en el tercer ciclo del Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya y está conformado por 18 integrantes que invierten en distintas actividades.

Cada una de la señoras cuenta con una actividad distinta e independiente pero siempre con el espíritu de unión y apoyo entre las integrantes así se comenta el caso de la  señora Susana P. quien  se dedica a la venta de ropas, esta actividad la realiza de diversas formas ya sea visitando a sus clientes o exponiendo frente a su casa sus productos, a ella le gusta mucho esta actividad ya  mediante la venta de sus productos puede ayudar a su marido con los gasto de la casa, el crédito lo destino para la compra de remeras, busos, pantalón, blusas, short, entre otros.
Se citan las actividades de las demás integrantes:

Venta de ropas

17
Alicia C.
Venta de joyas
18
Liliana R.
Venta de Bebidas
texts.en:
The Kuña Guapa committee from Luque’s San Juan neighborhood was organized thanks to an invitation from the Divino Niño Jesús committee of the same neighborhood to form a new group. Currently, the committee is in its third loan cycle with Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya and is composed of 18 members who invest in various commercial activities. Each woman has a different and independent line or work but all share the spirit of unity and mutual help among themselves. We can emphasize Susana P.’s case: she sells clothing in various sales modalities. Sometimes she visits customers in their homes, other times she sets up a sales stand in front of her house. She enjoys her work very much because, through her sales, she is able to help her husband meet household expenses. She will use the funds to buy t-shirts, sweaters, pants, blouses, shorts, etc. The other members are involved in the following activities: 1 Susana P. Clothing sales 2 Romi C. Athletic shoe sales 3 Filomena A. Dairy products sales 4 Julia Y. Costume Jewelry Sales 5 Antonia E. Food Sales 6 Flamilia B. Handicrafts 7 Eulalia Y. Food Sales 8 Aida D. Lingerie Sales 9 María Cristina R. Clothing Sales 10 Digna R. Beverages Sales 11 Luciana A. Charcoal Sales 12 Myrian G. Stationery Store 13 Sonia Y. Clothing Sales 14 Mirtha A. Clothing Sales 15 Lucia R. Beverage and Food Sales 16 Mirta S. Beverage Sales 17 Alicia C. Jewelry Sales 18 Liliana R. Beverage Sales

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy assorted clothing.

loans.name: Funes Mendoza Group

texts.es: Grupo Solidario F. M. está conformado por 2 personas muy trabajadoras. Alejandrina tiene 66 años y su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 21 años que se ha dedicado a dedicado a mejorar sus ingresos por medio este logro proporcionarle a sus 4 hijos los estudios necesarios y que fueran personas de bien, actualmente trabajan de manera independiente. Su amiga Ángela Martina se dedica  a una pulpería, ella inicio porque su amiga Alejandrina  le proporciono el apoyo para que estableciera su propio negocio en su vivienda. Ellas solicitan este financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para materia prima. Sus deseos es seguir con vida y continuar trabajando.
texts.en:
The F. M. Solidarity Group consists of two hardworking individuals. Alejandrina is 66 years old and manages a grocery store. For more than 21 years, she has focused on improving her income through this business so that she could provide for her four children and supply them with an education. As a result, they developed to become good people. She currently works independently.

Her friend Ángela Martina also runs a grocery store. Ángela started her business because her friend Alejandrina helped her to establish it from home. They are requesting a loan to use as operating capital to acquire raw materials. Their hopes are to carry on with their lives and continue working.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to acquire more merchandise

loans.name: Anathalie

texts.en:
Anathalie is 36 years old and is married with one child who is 12 years old. Anathalie lives in Gakenke and for about five years has been a hardworking businesswoman selling a variety of fruits and some foodstuffs. The hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Anathalie needs to expand her business through purchasing more fruits so that she can satisfy the demands of her customers. In addition, she is also planning the business of selling wheat as her customers used to ask her about this product.

With the use of this loan, if her plan of expanding her business is successful, Anathalie hopes to earn more profits. With these profits, she will reinvest one portion in the business and the remaining portion will be used in taking care of her little family and purchasing a cow to raise at home.

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of fruits and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Constantine

texts.en:
Constantine is 28 years old and is married with two children who are 3 and 6 years old. Constantine and her family live in Nyarugenge district, a region of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Here, Constantine has been in the business of selling clothes for about five years and the hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Constantine needs a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her original investment so that she is able to purchase more attractive styles for young people. With these attractive styles of clothes, Constantine will hopefully earn more profits and she will use these profits to reinvest in her business.

Once she arrives to this level, Constantine will continue to do her best so that she can keep her business financially stable.

loans.use: To buy additional styles of clothes to sell

loans.name: Maria Del Pilar

texts.es: Maria Del Pilar tiene 59 años, su actividad económica es una pulpería por lo que siempre ha logrado salir adelante. Esta Señora no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos pues han sido una gran ayuda para su negocio. Maria tiene más de 31 años de obtener esta actividad, por lo que siempre ha sido muy popular en su cuadra pues sus vecinos han recurrido a su vivienda en busca de granos básicos que a diario se utiliza, es una persona muy humilde pero trabajadora. Ella solicita este financiamiento para la compra de arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, café, papel, golosinas y gaseosas para no perder a sus clientes. Su deseo es mantener activo su negocio ya que hay mucha competencia pero no todos ofrecen el carisma que ella ofrece a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Maria Del Pilar is 59 years old. She has been able to stay ahead because of the grocery store that she manages. This is not the first time Maria has received a loan and the previous ones that she obtained have been a great help to her business. She has been in business for more than 31 years and is very popular since neighbors come to her to buy basic grains on a daily basis. Maria is a humble, yet hardworking person.

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy rice, beans, sugar, oil, coffee, paper, candy, and sodas so that she will not lose customers. Her desire is to remain active in her business since there is much competition. However, not everyone serves their customers with as charismatic a personality as she does.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: María Blanca Rosa

texts.es: María Blanca Rosa C. D. G. D. 35 años D. edad, resiD. en el Municipio D. Sensuntepeque, ubicado en el departamento D. Cuscatlán. Vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja como agricultor, y albañil, así mismo junto a sus dos hijos D. 7 y 5 años D. edad. María se dedica a la venta D. productos D. bellezas como cremas, maquillaje y perfumes D. catálogos, los cuales  venD. D. forma ambulante, ofreciéndoselo a sus vecinas y personas D. otros lugares del mismo municipio, todo con el fin D. poder mostrar sus producto a mayor cantidad D. personas y D. esta manera aumentar la posibilidad D. sus ventas. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. productos, así D. esta manera María podrá ofrecer más variedad, lo cual le permitirá tener mayor clientela. Para María el mejorar su negocio es D. suma importancia, ya que en gran manera es a través D. este como logran solventar muchos gastos del hogar, y como toda buena mujer D. hogar ella desea poder darles todo lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
María Blanca Rosa C. D. G. is 35 years old and lives in the town of Sensuntepeque, located in the Department of Cuscatlán. She lives with her husband, who works as both a farmer and a mason, and their two children, ages 7 and 5. María offers beauty products such as crèmes, make-up, and perfumes through a catalog. She sells her products as a traveling merchant, presenting them to her neighbors and other people who live in different parts of town. María tries to hold demonstrations in front of as many people as possible in an attempt to increase her sales.

She is requesting a loan so that she can buy more products, and as a result, offer a greater variety so that she can attract more customers. For María, improving her business is of great importance because this is the means by which she meets her household expenses. Like every good woman, she wants to proviD. the best for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Hermenegildo

texts.es:
El Sr. Hermenegildo Veron de 50 años esta casado con la señora Claudia Ramirez de 40 años, poseen 3 hijos cursando el colegio actualmente.
El señor trabajo 11 años para una empresa privada y se jubilo con los años y con los ahorros que poseía mas la jubilación que cobro abrió  una peluquería que administra su señora. Tambien posee una mercería en el mercado en donde el es encargado y administrador, sus mayores clientes son los visitantes del mercado.
En el futuro le gustaría  abrir una tienda con local propio y que sus hijos concluyan la universidad ya que el no tuvo la oportunidad de terminar su carrera universitaria.

El préstamo fue invertido en la compra de artículos para mercería como son hilos, agujas, gomas, botones etc.
texts.en:
Sr. Hermenegildo Veron is 50 years old and married to Sra. Claudia Ramirez, who is 40. They have three children who are currently attending high school.

Hermenegildo worked for a private company for eleven years. After he retired, he used the savings he accumulated over the years to open a beauty salon that his wife operates. He also manages a vending post at the market where he sells sewing supplies. His main customers are visitors who come to the market. In the future, he would like to have his own location where he can open a store. He hopes to see his children complete their university education since he did not have the opportunity to finish his college degree.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy sewing supplies such as thread, needles, elastic bands, buttons, and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase thread, needles, elastic bands, buttons, and other items

loans.name: María Ángel

texts.es: María ángel H. D. G. D. 39 años D. edad, resiD. en el Municipio D. Sensuntepeque, ubicado en el departamento D. Cuscatlán. Vive junto a su familia la cual esta conformada por su esposo quien se dedica a trabajar como motoristas D. buses del trasporte público, y junto a sus dos hijos, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. María posee una venta D. tortillas y una pupusería, las tortillas las elabora en la mediodía, y las pupusas por las tarD., D. esta manera, ella ha podido obtener ganancias, las cuales le han permitido sostener su hogar junto a su esposo. Es por esto que ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar maíz por mayor, D. esta manera ella podrá elaborar mayor cantidad D. productos, los cuales tienen mucha demanda en el lugar por la calidad con la que María los elabora. Lo que más anhela María es mejorar las condiciones D. su negocio D. manera que le genere mayores ganancias y D. esta forma brindarle una mejor estabilidad económica a su familia.
texts.en:
María Ángel H. D. G. is 39 years old and a resident of the town of Sensuntepeque, located in the Department of Cuscatlán. She lives with her family that consists of her husband, who works as a public bus driver, and their two school-age children. María has a business selling tortillas and pupusas. She makes the tortillas around noon and then sells pupusas in the afternoons. This is how she is able to earn income to help her husband with maintaining their household.

For this reason, she is requesting a loan so that she can buy corn in large quantities and continue to make more of her products. Her food is in high demand because of the quality of its preparation. What María wants most is to improve the condition of her business so that she can generate more income and proviD. better financial stability for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn in large quantities

loans.name: Martha Marlene

texts.es: Martha Marlene tiene 31 años de edad, su actividad económica es la venta de madera. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este humilde negocio, es una joven muy responsable y luchadora. Ella inicio este negocio por su esposo que es aserrador y con la experiencia que le ha obtenido decidió implementar la venta de madera en su vivienda, para que su esposa obtuviera un medio de ingresos ya que sus 2 hijos están my pequeños y están a su cargo. Martha tiene muchos sueños pero le gustaría hacer realidad ampliar su vivienda para agrandar su negocio. ella solicita este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima y ofrecer más productos a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Martha Marlene, 31, sells lumber. She has been in this humble line of work for over 5 years; she is a responsible and tenacious young woman. She started her business thanks to her husband, who is a sawyer. With the experience he had gained, he decided to set up a lumber sales business in their home so that his wife could have a source of income while still being able to care for their two, small children. Martha has many dreams for the future; the main one being enlarging her house so that she can expand her business. She is asking for this funding to buy lumber so that she can offer more variety of product to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy lumber.

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina is a 51-year-old woman, married with four children. Her children are doing well in school. She sells household and gift items like cooking pots, plates and cups. Tina has been in this business for a long time and she uses her experience to attract and retain more customers. She hopes to grow her business. Her greatest challenge in her business is funds and she hopes to overcome this challenge. Tina is a very hard working woman. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 80,000 and to purchase more household and gift items. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more household and gift items to sell.

loans.name: Zoila Estela

texts.es: Zoila estela A. D. M. D. 60 años D. edad, resiD. en el Municipio D. Ilopango, ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador. Vive únicamente junto a su esposo quien trabaja como peluquero. Zoila posee una venta D. sopa muy típica D. este país llamada “sopa D. pata”, la cual esta hecha a base D. piernas D. res y verduras, esta sopa es muy popular, y solicitada por las personas. Zoila elabora y comercializa esta sopa, en el mercado central D. San Salvador, uno D. los mercados más grandes D. la capital, en donD. exixte una gran competencia entre las diferentes ventas D. comida. DesD. hace 16 años que Zoila se dedica a este tipo D. trabajo, logrando obtener gran fama por darle un toque muy especial a su producto, en su lugar D. trabajo es muy conocida y respetada por ser una señora muy trabajadora y amable, tanto con sus clientes como con las personas que le ayudan en el negocio. Zoila solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar toda la materia prima para la elaboración D. esta exquisita sopa, ya que es gracias a este negocio como ella ha logrado seguir adelante junto a su esposo, trabajando mucho por poder tener una vida digna.
texts.en:
Zoila Estela A. D. M., 60, lives in Ilopango, San Salvador department. She lives with her husband, who is a barber. She sells a kind of soup that is very typical of this country, called "Sopa D. Pata," which is maD. based on beef leg and vegetables. This is a very popular, sought-after dish. Zoila makes and sells this soup in San Salvador's central market, one of the capital's largest and a site where there is much competition in food sales. Zoila has been in this type of work for 16 years and has acquired a bit of fame due to the special touch she adds to her product; she is very respected and known for being hard-working and kind both to her customers and to the persons who help her in her business. Zoila is asking for funding to buy the raw materials needed to make this delicious soup because, thanks to this business, she and her husband have managed to get ahead working hard to have a dignified life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beef and vegetables.

loans.name: Lilian Roxana

texts.es: Lilian Roxana S. R. de 30 años de edad, reside en el Municipio de Soyapango. Vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja como catedrático de una universidad nacional, así mismo junto a sus tres hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar.
